And who would be the real boss? Mr. King, a model? Mr. Swanhaus, a marketer? Or Ms. Radziwill, a Real Housewife on TV and real author?

title: Israel Rabbinical Authorities Promise Clarity in Conversions Abroad
description: JERUSALEM  After years of obfuscation and a high-profile dispute concerning an esteemed New York rabbi who converted Ivanka Trump, Israels rabbinical authorities announced this week that they would convene to establish clear criteria for recognizing Orthodox conversions done abroad.

title: Selling Yachts in an Office That Rises and Falls With the Tides
description: Tucker Fallon, a yacht broker, keeps pieces of nautical history in his office, which is on a houseboat in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Popcast: The Best Albums of 2016
description: One of the unexpected byproducts of the streaming era is how a certain tier of artists  already famous, prone to eccentricity  have doubled down on albums. These blocks of work demand to be consumed as a whole, and serve as an enemy of the ephemerality of music consumption.

title: Is the Professor Watchlist a Threat to Free Speech?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Playlist: Taylor Swift and the Jesus and Mary Chain Offer Different Shades of Teases
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

title: Telling Their Life Stories, Older Adults Find Peace in Looking Back
description: ISABELLA S. BICKS parents, both Jewish physicians, never talked about the past after the family moved from Fascist Italy to the United States in 1939. She was 8 at the time and quickly learned it was best to keep her feelings of loss and loneliness to herself.

title: Monkeys Could Talk, but They Dont Have the Brains for It
description: Primates are unquestionably clever: Monkeys can learn how to use money, and chimpanzees have a knack for game theory. But no one has ever taught a nonhuman primate to say hello.

title: Everyday Racist Objects
description: Join us Wednesday for a live conversation with Logan Jaffe, a mediamaker embedded with The New York Timess Race/Related team, to discuss the commodification of prejudice.

title: The Immigrants: Dreamers Give Back
description: To the Editor:

title: Confronting Racist Objects
description: Millions of racist objects sit in the homes of everyday Americans. Here are some of your stories about reconciling, reclaiming and reinterpreting them.

title: A Political Horror Show of Recounts, 16 Years After Hanging Chads
description: DETROIT  The recount of the presidential election ended on Wednesday night as abruptly as it had begun. By Thursday, workers were packing away canvas bags of ballots, board records and tables and chairs. A legal battle halted proceedings before all of Michigans votes were counted again, but not before a flood of perplexing peculiarities emerged.

title: High on Hitler and Meth: Book Says Nazis Were Fueled by Drugs
description: Given the sheer tonnage of books already devoted to the Nazis and Hitler, you might assume that everything interesting, terrible and bizarre is already known about one of historys most notorious regimes and its genocidal leader. Then along comes Norman Ohler, a soft-spoken 46-year-old novelist from Berlin, who rummages through military archives and emerges with this startling fact: The Third Reich was on drugs.

title: Uninformed About Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Against the Veil in Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Alexi Lalas on M.L.S., American Soccer and Where All That Hair Went
description: Alexi Lalas won one Major League Soccer title as a player and has seen many more as a broadcaster. On Saturday night, when Toronto F.C. hosts the Seattle Sounders in the M.L.S. Cup, he will watch another in his role as an analyst for Fox Sports. This past week, before heading to Toronto, Lalas sat down with a group of New York Times editors to discuss M.L.S., Bruce Arena and just what American soccer is, and what it can be.

title: Andrew Puzder, Donald Trumps Choice for Labor Post
description: To the Editor:

title: If You Resist, You Get Hurt, or Die: Filipinos Praise Dutertes Antidrug Campaign
description: Many Filipinos say President Rodrigo Dutertes brutal antidrug campaign, which has killed thousands of people suspected of being dealers or addicts, is a welcome antidote to the fear they say has gripped the Philippines for decades.

title: A Final Godspeed, John Glenn
description: To the Editor:

title: Jurors Hear Dylann Roof Explain Shooting in Video: I Had to Do It
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Shortly after being arrested and about 17 hours after he shot up the fellowship hall at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church, Dylann S. Roof sat at an oval conference table with two F.B.I. agents and confessed  calmly, clinically, occasionally chortling  to killing nine people who he acknowledged could not have been more innocent.

title: Seven Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now  That Would Make Great Gifts
description: A by-no-means-exhaustive list of items wed like to give (and get) this season.

title: The Dick Van Dyke Show in Color? See It on Sunday
description: On Sunday, colorization is coming to one of televisions great comedies, The Dick Van Dyke Show, and perhaps grousing will be heard in some quarters from holdouts who still object to mucking with black-and-white classics. Me, Im looking forward to it. Ive seen these episodes many times before, but the color  at least based on the excerpts Ive seen  wakes them up.

title: Fiercely Debated Water Level Plan Is Adopted for Lake Ontario
description: ALBANY  An international commission on Thursday gave its final approval to a pact that will regulate the water level and it hopes repair the ecosystems of Lake Ontario.

title: Goldman Sachs to Extend Its Reach in Trump Administration
description: Goldman Sachss outsize influence in Washington is about to get larger.

title: A Rooming House for Career-Minded New York Women
description: Sarah Berkes was delighted, if also very surprised, to find that a place like the Webster Apartments on West 34th Street still existed in New York City. The stately rooming house for career minded professional women where she has lived for a little over a year is one of the few of its kind left in the city.

title: The Roots of Implicit Bias
description: During the first presidential debate, Hillary Clinton argued that implicit bias is a problem for everyone, not just police. Her comment moved to the forefront of public conversation an issue that scientists have been studying for decades: namely, that even well-meaning people frequently harbor hidden prejudices against members of other racial groups. Studies have shown that these subtle biases are widespread and associated with discrimination in legal, economic and organizational settings.

title: Transition Questionnaire Raises Concerns
description: A questionnaire from President-elect Donald J. Trump's transition team, obtained by The New York Times, asks Energy Department employees pointed questions not only about climate change policy but also about the size of the department and efforts to promote nuclear power, which the transition team seems to favor.

title: Can We Fix a Poisoned Planet Once Weve Poisoned the Social Compact?
description: As I watched the returns come in on election night with my 2-month-old son, my thoughts turned to dust.

title: Nina Jacobson Has Her Revenge on Hollywoods Old-Boy Network
description: LOS ANGELES  Most mornings, Nina Jacobson drives her gray 2012 Tesla from her home in Brentwood to her office in Santa Monica with her two Australian shepherds, Hero and Pearl, in the back seat.

title: Canada Today: Emissions Policy, Bird-Hunting and Meat Pie
description: Donald J. Trump has not yet moved into the White House but his anticipated policies are already spurring debate over what actions, if any, Canada will need to take in response. That was the case on Friday when Prime Minister Justin Trudeau met with the provincial and territorial leaders to work out a national approach to pricing on carbon emissions. Before the meeting, Mr. Trudeau set out a plan where the price  either through a fossil fuel tax or a cap-and-trade system of emission allowances  would reach 50 Canadian dollars, or about $38, a metric ton, or 2,205 pounds, over five years. He also warned that provinces that did not buy in would have the price imposed on them. During the presidential election campaign, Mr. Trump said that he would pull the United States out of the climate change commitments made by the Obama administration. Some Canadians, mostly Conservative politicians, say the economy will be in jeopardy if Canada goes ahead with carbon pricing in the absence of American action. But when I looked into the debate, I also found people who argued that moving now on carbon emissions could give Canada a competitive advantage.

title: Think Like a Doctor: The Builders Blisters Solved!
description: On Thursday we asked Well readers to take on the difficult case of a 64-year-old contractor who had had a blistering rash on his hands off and on for over 20 years. The man saw the rash as simply annoying, but the diagnosis suggested an important underlying medical problem. Your challenge was to identify both the cause of the rash as well as the underlying diagnosis.

title: The Torture Report Must Be Saved
description: In President Obamas final national security speech on Tuesday, he spoke about the importance of staying true to our values, of not returning to torture, and of transparency. Now, in his remaining time in office, he has an opportunity to take action to advance these goals and to do something of great importance for the publics understanding of our history. He has the ability to protect the Senate Intelligence Committees full 6,700-page report on torture from being lost, perhaps forever.

title: Calls Arent Allowed on Planes, but Regulators Consider a Warning Anyway
description: Over time, airline passengers have been deprived of comfortable seats, passable food, space for some carry-on luggage, leg room, head room, arm room and any other amenities that may separate humans from cattle.

title: German Panel Rules That a Rare Violin Was Looted by Nazis
description: In its first ruling on a matter involving a musical instrument, a German panel established to mediate disputes over cultural objects looted during the Third Reich has decided that a Nuremberg foundation should compensate the heirs of a man whose prized 18th-century violin is thought to have been confiscated by the Nazis or lost following a forced sale.

title: Senate Democrats Relent, Averting Government Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Friday relented in their flirtation with a government shutdown over a dispute about health care benefits for coal miners, and with less than an hour before the midnight deadline, the Senate approved a measure to fund the government through April.

title: Refugees Arrest Turns a Crime Into National News (and Debate) in Germany
description: BERLIN  When a 19-year-old medical student was found raped and drowned in the university city of Freiburg in October, it was seen as a sad and awful crime, but a local one. Beyond a few tabloids, the story failed to make national headlines.

title: Vibrant Peppercorns (and Their Impostors) Brighten Fish Fillets
description: I had pepper on the brain this week, so much so that when I was thinking about a simple butter sauce for some halibut fillets, peppercorns, many of them, had to be part of the picture.

title: Murdochs Take Another Shot at Sky
description: The Murdochs are having another shot at Sky. On Friday, 21st Century Fox offered to buy the 61 percent of Sky, the European pay-TV group, that it does not own. The proposal notionally values Sky at 18.5 billion pounds ($23 billion), though only about 11.3 billion would change hands. Circumstances look a lot more auspicious than the last time Rupert Murdoch and his family tried to consolidate the business, in 2010.

title: 40 Minutes With Kellyanne Conway
description: Kellyanne Conway knows all about the caricature of her. And the criticisms of her work for Donald J. Trump. And the questions about whether she will go to work in the White House.

title: The Top Places to Eat Well and Cheaply
description: Ligaya Mishans favorite inexpensive places to eat in New York City this year.

title: The Top 10 Cheap (and Astonishing) Places to Eat in 2016
description: Almost all my favorite meals this year were made by people from far away, who left behind the countries of their birth to make a life in this one. By choice or necessity, they turned to the kitchen and became quiet ambassadors for the food of their childhoods.

title: The High Line
description: Give me such shows! give me the streets of Manhattan!

title: Voyeur | The High Line
description: A stroll along the High Line provides many perspectives.

title: Giuliani: Tactically Pugnacious
description: Throughout his long career as a U.S. Attorney, Mayor of New York, presidential contender and Donald Trump surrogate, Rudy Giuliani has often used his combative personality strategically.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Donald Trump, Russia, Aleppo: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Donald Trump, in Louisiana, Says He Will End Energy Regulations
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  President-elect Donald J. Trump promised on Friday that his administration would strip away job-killing restrictions on energy production and encourage the construction of refineries in the United States, as he campaigned for Republican candidates in a state heavily dependent on the oil and gas industry.

title: Wary Drug Makers Move to Fend Off Further Attacks Under Donald Trump
description: If the nations pharmaceutical executives thought Donald J. Trump would grant them a reprieve from scrutiny over high drug prices, he made them reconsider that idea in the last few days.

title: How Islands of Honesty Can Crush a System of Corruption
description: For over a year, a global mystery has been growing: Why are so many governments around the world collapsing amid corruption scandals?

title: M.L.S. Is Bypassing Big Names for Big (and Young) Talent
description: For a decade, Major League Soccer has reserved its designated player label for the stars it considers the leagues crown jewels. David Beckham. Thierry Henry. David Villa. Didier Drogba.

title: Mark Morriss Party With Robots, Barbie and a Nutcracker
description: It is an unwritten law that every new production of The Nutcracker must tell a story that is somehow different from any other. Although the original 1892 ballet  unusual for 19th-century repertory  told no love story, many current productions have injected romance, and a few have sex, too. Modern-dress Nutcrackers are not unusual.

title: Dylan, Polite? It Aint Him, Babe
description: STOCKHOLM  Im Not There was the title of a 2007 movie about the exquisite elusiveness of the singer Bob Dylan. It is also the unofficial theme of the week in Stockholm, where Mr. Dylan, who won the 2016 Nobel Prize in Literature, is not here to accept it.

title: Classical Music This Week
description: Were happy to introduce a new weekly roundup of classical music coverage, appearing in print every Saturday.

title: How to Play the Trump Stock Market Rally
description: In the four weeks since Donald J. Trump was elected president, many stocks have soared and the markets winners have been clustered around a specific theme: an inflating economy.

title: Paris Imposes Measures to Fight Pollution, With Mixed Results
description: PARIS  Even those who love Paris have been frustrated this week by a choking haze that descended on the city, irritating residents eyes and throats and leading officials to limit the number of cars on the road.

title: As Womens Hockey Advances in Canada, Pay Checks May Not Be Far Behind
description: BOSTON  Kristina Brown, a forward for the Boston Blades in the Canadian Womens Hockey League, also works full time as a project engineer on a 32-story condo and apartment complex being built near Fenway Park.

title: The World's Most Corrupt Countries
description: Transparency International, an anti-corruption watchdog, has compiled a list of the worlds most corrupt countries.

title: Trump Spent Far Less Than Clinton, but Paid His Companies Well
description: WASHINGTON  Donald J. Trump won the White House after spending a little more than half of what Hillary Clinton did, using a combination of his own money and contributions from donors big and small to fuel a campaign that shattered the modern conventions of money and politics.

title: The Dylann Roof Trial: The Evidence
description: Prosecutors and defense lawyers are introducing scores of exhibits in the federal trial of Dylann S. Roof, the self-avowed white supremacist who is accused of killing nine black people at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church. Although the judge has forbidden the release of some exhibits, such as certain crime scene photographs, he has allowed many to be made public beyond the courtroom.

title: Operator Is at Fault for Fatal Crane Accident, City Finds
description: The operator of a crane that collapsed and killed one person in Lower Manhattan in February failed to properly lower the boom and was responsible for the accident, New York City officials said on Friday.

title: No People in Sight Yet, but South Bronx Gets Ready for Development
description: The bustling riverfront envisioned for a tattered stretch of warehouses and parking lots in the South Bronx is still many years away.

title: Cheer Up, Andrew Rosenthal! Podcast Listeners Send Along Good News
description: In Good, Bad and Mad: Andrew Rosenthal on the News, a regular Inside the Times podcast, the Times Op-ed columnist Andrew Rosenthal talks about the news  the good, the bad and that which makes him mad.

title: Restaurant Recession From Health Care Act? Little Evidence
description: Of all the policy positions taken by Andrew F. Puzder, the fast-food chief executive whom Donald J. Trump has chosen to be his secretary of labor, one he returns to with regularity is his passionate disdain for the Affordable Care Act and its effect on businesses and workers.

title: Want to Visit the Jazz Age? Try Fight Night in Vegas
description: Its always 1926 at the fights. A horse-and-wagon tang of atavism drifts in the air as boxers throw traditional punches  jabs, crosses and hooks  and voices from the crowd call out timeless advice: To the body! The body!

title: Review: Transgender Street Children, Out on a Pier
description: The characters in some plays  generally the not-so-good ones  leave your consciousness almost as soon as you leave the theater. Others stay a while, or never leave at all. Im confident that the three central characters in Street Children, an affecting and saucily funny new play by Pia Scala-Zankel, about transgender youth living on the harsh streets of New York in the 1980s, will remain with me for good. But also, given the dark turns their lives take, for not-so-good.

title: Key Figure in South Korean Leaders Troubles: A Puppy
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Did a fight over a puppy lead to the vote to impeach South Koreas leader? A whistle-blower whose account has riveted South Koreans says it did.

title: For John Glenn, a Rare Repeat Tour of the Canyon of Heroes
description: It is March 1, 1962. There is bright sunshine across Lower Manhattan, and a crowd is building. New Yorkers still love a parade. The ritual of throwing blizzards of ticker tape from the windows of stock brokerages has become a cherished tradition. People are lining the sidewalks of Broadway, two deep, then four deep, then six deep. And they keep arriving.

title: To Carmelo Anthony, Phil Jacksons Comments Are a Temporary Black Cloud
description: Carmelo Anthony addressed on Friday the latest controversy involving Phil Jackson  one that happens to involve Anthony himself. Anthony, the Knicks star, said he had not spoken to Jackson, the Knicks president, since Jackson chided him in an interview this week for having a tendency to hold onto the ball too long.

title: Japanese Leaders Pearl Harbor Visit May Not Be a First, After All
description: TOKYO  When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said this week that he would visit Pearl Harbor with President Obama, news organizations around the world reported that the visit would be the first ever by a Japanese premier to the naval base that his country attacked in 1941.

title: Facebook Reports New Issues With Ad-Counting Tools
description: SAN FRANCISCO  One of Facebooks biggest appeals to advertisers is its wealth of data on the millions of people who use the site daily. Yet the social network recently has come under scrutiny from some of its biggest advertisers for errors in that data.

title: Columbia Graduate Students Vote Overwhelmingly to Unionize
description: Graduate students at Columbia University voted to unionize this week, the group announced on Friday. The union will be the first to represent graduate students since the National Labor Relations Board ruled in August that students who work as teaching and research assistants have a federal right to unionize.

title: Trumps Honeymoon Begins: Confidence in the Economy Is Booming
description: Consumers say they are more confident. Business leaders, once wary, are now expressing excitement that one of their own is headed toward the White House. And Wall Street is bordering on the ecstatic.

title: After Burst Radiator Kills 2 Girls, Investigators Scrutinize Bronx Building
description: Two days after a steam radiator burst in homeless housing in the Bronx, killing two young sisters, investigators from several city agencies  the Police Department, child welfare services and the Buildings Department  pored over physical evidence and records to distill what Mayor Bill de Blasio has called a freak accident.

title: Trump Isnt Rewarding a Lot of Loyalists with Cabinet Jobs. Heres Why.
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump boasted throughout the presidential campaign of his loyalty as a singular quality. Folks, look, Im a loyal person, Mr. Trump said at a CNN town hall in April, explaining why he would not rid his campaign of a staff member who was under fire.

title: After Russias Spree of Doping, a Time to Reform
description: Russia is an unrepentant sporting reprobate.

title: Climate Change Conversations Are Targeted in Questionnaire to Energy Department
description: WASHINGTON  President-elect Donald J. Trumps transition team has circulated an unusual 74-point questionnaire at the Department of Energy that requests the names of all employees and contractors who have attended climate change policy conferences, as well as emails and documents associated with the conferences.

title: Prudential Wrongful Termination Lawsuit
description: Three managers in Prudentials corporate investigation division found signs that Wells Fargo had signed up customers for insurance without the customers knowledge.

title: Yahya Jammeh, Gambian President, Now Refuses to Accept Election Defeat
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The fate of the presidency in Gambia took a peculiar turn Friday night when the longtime incumbent appeared on state television to announce that he was rejecting the results of last weeks vote that ousted him. He also called for new elections.

title: Accusations of Fraud at Wells Fargo Spread to Sham Insurance Policies
description: When Wells Fargo admitted a few months ago that thousands of its employees had created as many as two million unauthorized accounts for its customers, alarm bells went off at Prudential, one of the nations biggest insurance firms.

title: East Timor Is Accused of Using Ineligible Players for Its Soccer Team
description: The soccer federation of East Timor, a small nation in the Indonesian archipelago, has been charged by Asias regional soccer governing body with using forged and falsified documents to field ineligible players on its national team, according to a spokeswoman for the governing body, the Asian Football Confederation.

title: Donald Trumps Military Government
description: Washington  A new president, swept into office on a tide of fake news and media manipulation, surrounds himself with generals: his adviser on foreign policy, the defense minister, his minister of the interior and the further possible appointments of foreign minister and intelligence director.

title: Herb Hardesty, Fats Dominos Saxophonist at Dawn of Rock n Roll, Dies at 91
description: Herb Hardesty, a tenor saxophonist whose name was synonymous with New Orleans rhythm and blues and early rock n roll and whose lyrical solos were heard on nearly all of Fats Dominos hit songs, died on Dec. 3 in Las Vegas. He was 91.

title: Exxon Mobil Chief Rises as Trumps Choice for Secretary of State
description: Rex W. Tillerson, the president and chief executive of Exxon Mobil, has emerged as President-elect Donald J. Trumps top choice to become secretary of state, according to a person with direct knowledge of the search process.

title: South Korean Corruption Will Endure
description: SEOUL, South Korea  There were euphoric cheers from the crowd outside the National Assembly on Friday when its speaker announced the outcome: By 234 to 56, South Korean lawmakers had voted to impeach President Park Geun-hye for her role in a corruption scandal that has paralyzed the country for two months. Her powers have been suspended, and Prime Minister Hwang Kyo-ahn has taken over as acting president.

title: One Job Is Enough. Sell the Hotel.
description: President-elect Donald Trump wont be stepping down from his role as an executive producer on The New Celebrity Apprentice  an unprecedented situation in which the commander in chief would have a job on the side.

title: Mika Kurosawa, Godmother of Japanese Contemporary Dance, Dies at 59
description: Mika Kurosawa, a choreographer and dancer who was considered by many to be the godmother of Japanese contemporary dance, died on Dec. 1 in Yokohama, Japan. She was 59.

title: Worker Dies in Fall at Old Domino Sugar Site in Brooklyn
description: A construction worker died on Friday after falling from scaffolding at the site of a residential development in Brooklyn, in what was at least the citys 11th construction death this year.

title: The Heisman Trophy Finalists
description: Sophomore quarterback, Louisville

title: An Apprentice Role for Trump Opens Door Wide for Questions
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump is entering office with financial entanglements that are exotic and far-flung: a condominium project in Manila, a luxury furniture maker in Istanbul, golf courses in Scotland and Ireland, and a hotel in Azerbaijan.

title: Restoring Trust in South Korea
description: It is understandable that South Koreans would celebrate after their Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Friday to impeach President Park Geun-hye, whose involvement with a shady and corrupt confidante has generated six weeks of huge street protests and demands for her resignation. The crisis, and Ms. Parks precipitous fall in public support, had made it all but impossible for her to function effectively.

title: Leader in a Suit
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Ill tell you what got me: PET HATES, at 7A. It was my mistake, because I tried to put a singular answer into a plural entry, but I just couldnt get pet peeve out of my head. I hate when that happens, dont you?

title: A Viral Twist to the Newtown Tragedy
description: NEWTOWN, Conn.  Its been four years since the gun carnage at Sandy Hook Elementary School took the lives of 20 first graders in a matter of minutes. The grief of the parents remains unfathomable. But their determined efforts to prevail beyond the mayhem have turned out to be creative and far-reaching.

title: With Election Defeat, Ghanas President Becomes Casualty of Faltering Economy
description: ACCRA, Ghana  In an election that became a referendum on Ghanas faltering economy, Nana Akufo-Addo, a leader of the opposition, surfaced Friday as the winner over the incumbent president, John Mahama.

title: Canada Strikes a Deal to Cut Carbon Emissions by Putting a Price on Them
description: OTTAWA  Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on Friday that Canada would introduce nationwide carbon pricing in 2018.

title: Corrections: December 10, 2016
description: EDITORS NOTE: INTERNATIONAL

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I could have walked out, and you know, thats just what I was thinking, but then I just like, I dont know, I dont want to say spur of the moment, but, you know, I just finally decided I had to do it.

title: Rebuild or Leave?
description: The first town chartered by African Americans has battled two 100-year storms in under 20 years. Some see the ruins of homes, many covered in mold, as a lost cause. Others vow to rebuild.

title: A Wrenching Decision Where Black History and Floods Intertwine
description: PRINCEVILLE, N.C.  Betty Cobbs house is a shell nearly two months after floodwaters went halfway up the walls of her one-story home.

title: With Mass Protests, South Koreans Wield a Familiar Weapon in a New Era
description: We called it the Yonsei Beach Club. It convened the last time South Koreans exploded in protest and forced a government to capitulate, in 1987, when a small band of reporters and photographers would assemble to chronicle the daily demonstrations by students at Yonsei University in Seoul.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: Mary Poppins and John Cena on S.N.L.
description: Have a jolly holiday with Mary Poppins. Or treat yourself to a helping of Christmas goo with Love Actually.

title: Colombia Reports Major Rise in Birth Defect Amid Zika Crisis
description: Colombia, which suffered a Zika epidemic that peaked in February, has reported four times as many cases of babies born with microcephaly this year as it did in 2015, providing more proof that the Zika virus causes brain damage in infants.

title: Xinjiang, Tense Chinese Region, Adopts Strict Internet Controls
description: URUMQI, China  The regional government of Chinas far western region of Xinjiang, which has grappled with ethnic violence, has put into effect strict regulations that punish people for spreading false information online.

title: Wall Street Is Europes Landlord. And Tenants Are Fighting Back.
description: DUBLIN  The Tobun family never missed a rental payment on their modest brick rowhouse in eight years. But in February, the couple, who have two young children, received a letter warning that they would have to leave their home when the lease expired. Forty of their neighbors got the same notice.

title: At Home With a New Prairie Companion
description: Chris Thile, the virtuoso mandolin player of Punch Brothers fame, took over hosting of A Prairie Home Companion this year. Hang with him as he crafts the music for the radio show's new sound.

title: The Rich History of Twinkies
description: In 1849, Robert B. Ward founded a small bakery on Broome Street in Lower Manhattan. His family would go on to create a baking empire that sold a cream-filled yellow spongecake around the world. Below is a look at key moments in the history of Hostess.

title: Just How Much Do the Top Private Equity Earners Make?
description: There is C.E.O. pay. Then there is private equity C.E.O. pay.

title: Might Does Not Make Right; Being in the Right Does.
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: Living In Bernal Heights, San Francisco
description: Property values have rapidly appreciated in this San Francisco neighborhood, but theres still a communal vibe  and a coyote.

title: Bernal Heights, San Francisco: An Inclusive Village With Lofty Prices
description: Back in 1987, when Jessica Burdman and her then-husband were shopping for a house in San Francisco, they found themselves priced out of their popular Noe Valley neighborhood. They looked southeast  and up  to nearby Bernal Heights. A working-class community, it offered small vintage houses on a severely raked hillside with majestic views, when you scrambled to the top. The couple paid $189,000 for a 900-square-foot house on a street not inappropriately called Bonview. They added a second floor.

title: How the Twinkie Made the Superrich Even Richer
description: As fans gathered on Rockefeller Plaza in Manhattan, Al Roker pulled up in a big red delivery truck, ready to give America what it wanted: Twinkies.

title: Dissecting the #PizzaGate Conspiracy Theories
description: PizzaGate: How a rumor grew into a fake news storm tailor-made for the internet.

title: Headphones of New York
description: People in the city perform their routines to the tune of individualized soundtracks.

title: In Search of the Perfect Headphones
description: A guide for the audiophile and the casual listener, from Beats to Sensaphonics.

title: Soak, Steam, Spritz: Its All Self-Care
description: In the days after the presidential election, Jessa Blades, an herbalist and makeup artist in Brooklyn who supported Hillary Clinton, was devastated. All I could think to do was blend a tea to control my stress, she said.

title: The H-Bomb Fizzles: The Harvard Brand Takes a Hit
description: There exists a species of person  typically a well-groomed overachiever  who, when asked where he or she went to college, rather than state its name directly, will provide a Russian nesting doll set of geographical responses.

title: My Headphones, My Self
description: You see them on every block: people being propelled through their routines listening to their own individualized soundtracks, with the outside world serving as a stage set.

title: River Cruising, Family-Style
description: While onboard entertainment is the focus of enormous ocean-faring ships, river cruises in Europe emphasize onshore activities  one major reason that families (recommended for ages 8 and up) are hopping aboard.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Why Facebook Cant Count
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: How Can a Co-op Shoo Away a Pigeon Complaint?
description: Q. Our co-op on the Upper West Side  is next door to a grocery store. Our back courtyard shares open space with  the grocery stores air vents and cooling system. Pigeons are  nesting around the stores cooling system, providing food for rats. Our co-op hired an exterminator, but so long as the nests remain, the problem continues. The stores management company has not returned our calls. When we called 311, we received a warning from the city that our building was in violation of health codes and would face fines if the pigeon problem was not resolved. We called 311 again to explain. The operator opened a new service complaint, but we have heard nothing back. That was six months ago. What recourse do we have?

title: Janna Miksis and Jason Canavan: He Wasnt Just Playing Sick. Fortunately.
description: Janna Elyse Miksis, the daughter of Mona Raskin Miksis and Gerald F. Miksis of Linwood, N.J., was married Dec. 10 to Jason Gerard Canavan, the son of Anna M. Canavan and John G. Canavan of Newtown Square, Pa. They were married at the Masonic Temple in Philadelphia under a provision of Pennsylvania law allowing self-uniting marriages.

title: Penn Station Inhabitant Finally Has a Home of Her Own
description: They called themselves the Penn Station Nation, a ragtag group of roughly 50 homeless people who congregated around New York Citys bustling transportation hub.

title: Richard McLaren, Antidoping Investigator, Pursues a Tricky, Exhausting Trail
description: LONDON  Eating a striped candy cane on Friday evening, Richard H. McLaren, the Canadian lawyer who threw international sports into tumult this year, exhaled, finally.

title: Variety Puzzle: Acrostic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  One of the funniest writers today is Alexandra Petri, who writes for The Washington Post. You can read her columns here, but todays acrostic quote is from her book A Field Guide to Awkward Silences.

title: Trump, Mocking Claim That Russia Hacked Election, at Odds with G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON  An extraordinary breach has emerged between President-elect Donald J. Trump and the national security establishment, with Mr. Trump mocking American intelligence assessments that Russia interfered in the election on his behalf, and top Republicans vowing investigations into Kremlin activities.

title: Full Dylann Roof Confession
description: F.B.I. agents questioned Dylann Roof for approximately two hours after he was arrested in connection with the 2015 church shooting in Charleston, S.C.

title: An Alt-Right Makeover Shrouds the Swastikas
description: A small but determined political organization in Detroit began to worry that its official symbol was a bit off-putting. With the groups central philosophy suddenly finding traction in the daily discourse, appearances mattered.

title: Im Prejudiced, He Said. Then We Kept Talking.
description: One morning in August, when I was a guest on C-Span, I got a phone call that took my breath away.

title: Donald Trumps Bottomless Secretarial Pool
description: Its not as if Donald Trump wants for self-amusement, but still I pity him the apparent end of his search for a secretary of state. He had such a blast with it.

title: Democrats Hone a New Message: Its the Economy, Everyone
description: WASHINGTON  It was a blunt, plain-spoken set of senators who gathered last Monday at the Washington home of Senator Heidi Heitkamp, Democrat of North Dakota, dining on Chinese food as they vented frustration about the missteps of the Democratic Party.

title: 'Unguardable Cole Beasley Is Dallas Cowboys Secret Weapon
description: FRISCO, Tex.  Cole Beasley began preparing for his current job, as the Dallas Cowboys slot receiver extraordinaire, in seventh grade.

title: Government's Exhibit 2-A
description: Sometime before his arrest in the North Carolina shootings, Dylann Roof wrote a journal that outlined some of his racist beliefs, as well as reflections about his own life.

title: Government's Exhibit 148-A
description: When investigators searched Dylann Roofs car after his arrest, they found a letter he had written to his mother.

title: One Man in Italy Begs for Asylum, and Another Decides His Fate
description: ROME  Traffic noise floated through an open window as a Bangladeshi migrant named Nanue Matabor took a seat inside a tiny immigration office in central Rome. Only 19, Mr. Matabor had waited months for this hearing. He was asking for the right to remain in Europe. His life was in the balance. He stared at the floor, terrified.

title: Gambians Face Uncertainty After President Rejects His Defeat
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Gambians on Saturday braced themselves for a period of tense uncertainty after President Yahya Jammeh announced that he rejected the results of an election that ousted him from office and demanded a new vote.

title: A Knicks Rookie Big Man Is Not Afraid to Throw an Elbow. Ask His Mom.
description: It was barely a month into his N.B.A. career when Willy Hernangomez began to build a reputation for himself as a physical and fearless player. When the Knicks faced Atlantas Dwight Howard, Hernangomez pushed and prodded and defended until Howard, one of the leagues great redwoods, finally had had enough, throwing an elbow at Hernangomez.

title: Mass Protests Across Seoul
description: Protesters took to the streets of South Korea's capital on Saturday to call for the resignation of President Park Geun-hye, a day after Parliament voted to impeach her.

title: The Dangers of Echo Chambers on Campus
description: After Donald Trumps election, some universities echoed with primal howls. Faculty members canceled classes for weeping, terrified students who asked: How could this possibly be happening?

title: U.S. to Send 200 More Troops to Syria in ISIS Fight
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The United States is sending 200 additional troops to Syria, nearly doubling the Pentagons presence there, to help thousands of Kurdish and Arab fighters massing for an assault on the Islamic States stronghold of Raqqa, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said here on Saturday.

title: Suicides Reported in India After Death of Jayalalithaa Jayaram
description: NEW DELHI  The governing party of the southern state of Tamil Nadu said on Saturday that nearly 300 of its followers had committed suicide or died of shock and despair upon learning of the death of the partys leader, Jayalalithaa Jayaram.

title: Slaughter in the Philippines
description: In the name of eliminating drug crime, President Rodrigo Duterte has plunged the Philippines into a nightmare of brutal slaughter. The police say that since July 1, they have killed more than 2,000 people suspected of drug-related crimes. In addition, more than 3,500 homicides remain unsolved, many at the hands of unknown vigilantes.

title: There Are No Child Sex Slaves at My Local Pizza Parlor
description: WASHINGTON  On any given day, locals flock to Comet Ping Pong, a pizza joint here not far from where I live, to eat, talk and, of course, play Ping-Pong. But last Sunday, a man armed with a military-style assault rifle and a pistol turned up for an entirely different reason: to see for himself whether the restaurant was indeed, as right-wing fake news reports and conspiracy websites have declared, the hub of a vile child sex-slavery ring masterminded by Hillary Clinton.

title: Truth and Lies in the Age of Trump
description: Donald Trump understood at least one thing better than almost everybody watching the 2016 election: The breakdown of a shared public reality built upon widely accepted facts represented not a hazard, but an opportunity.

title: Trump Is a Great Storyteller. We Need to Be Better.
description: My son is 3 years old. Every morning and evening I read to him. I love the joy he takes in learning new words, immersing himself in stories, seeing himself as the characters, and acquiring a moral and ethical sense. He lives in a fictional world of good and bad, of threat and rescue, of the choice between doing good or doing harm.

title: His Sign Said Please Help. So I Tried.
description: Urbana, Ill.  This is not for the companionship of ladies, I tell Wes, handing over two $20 bills. Im breaking one of my own rules. If I give him money, its his. He can have himself a big old party if he wants.

title: Violence and Division on Chicagos South Side
description: CHICAGO  On the Saturday before the presidential election, in the city Donald J. Trump had cast during his campaign as the nightmare of urban America, a Chicago police officer killed a 25-year-old black man. According to police accounts, Joshua Beal and his family were leaving the funeral of a relative when they got into a traffic altercation with an off-duty fireman. An off-duty police officer and a uniformed sergeant joined the fray. When Mr. Beal failed to drop his weapon, he was shot multiple times by one or both of the officers.

title: Which Date Should Live in Infamy?
description: Winston Churchill was ebullient; he thought it was all over at last. On the evening of Sunday, Dec. 7, 1941, hosting a small birthday dinner at Chequers, the prime ministers country retreat, for Kathleen Harriman, the daughter of the American diplomat W. Averell Harriman, Churchill heard the news of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor from the BBC. At this very moment I knew the United States was in the war, up to the neck and in to the death, he wrote in his war memoirs. So we had won after all! After standing alone against Berlin since the German invasion of Poland on the first day of September 1939, struggling to engage an isolationist America, Churchill slept the sleep of the saved and thankful.

title: How to Stop a Black Snake
description: Near Cannon Ball, N.D.  Last Sunday, the Oceti Sakowin camp at Standing Rock in North Dakota was slick with icy, packed-down snow. The mud was glass. Veterans poured in, having traveled all night to support the people protecting their water from the Dakota Access Pipeline.

title: Should I Lie About My Beliefs to Get Health Insurance?
description: Boulder, Colo.  HERES an ethical dilemma. If you could save your family more than $8,000 next year simply by signing a statement affirming belief in principles you find repugnant, would you?

title: The Supersize Clich in Moana
description: Draw a circle. Give it stumpy legs, beer-keg arms, a big head of hair and a necklace of teeth. Draw some leaves around its middle, for modesty, and cover everything else in tattoos.

title: We Are Dead Either Way: Agonizing Choices for Syrians in Aleppo
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  He had long been one of the more optimistic anti-government residents of the besieged, rebel-held section of Aleppo, trying to buoy others spirits even as loyalist forces closed in. But as the Syrian Army and allied militias took more and more territory in an apparently decisive offensive during the week, Yasser Hmeish, an accountant for the local medical council, grew frantic.

title: Russia and Others Join OPEC in Rare, Coordinated Push to Cut Oil Output
description: Russia and other oil producers agreed on Saturday to join OPEC nations in a rare, coordinated reduction in oil output meant to lift petroleum prices and revenues to shore up their sagging government budgets.

title: Pressing the Off Button on an Indelible Marathon of Images
description: And now, after 25 years covering sports media for The New York Times, Im off to the obituaries department. Live sports to dead folks? I needed a new challenge, time away from pregame shows that have become indistinguishable towers of babble, three-man broadcast booths (deliver me from low-talking Cal Ripken Jr. on TBS baseball) and treacly, genteel Masters coverage that is done to please the overlords at Augusta.

title: Its Our Land. Lets Keep It That Way.
description: Bozeman, Mont.  The Statue of Liberty stands on a piece of federal land, but federal doesnt mean it belongs to Washington. This piece of real estate, 15 precious acres known as Liberty Island, lies in Upper New York Bay just west of the state line between New York and New Jersey, but it doesnt belong to New Jersey. Liberty Island is part of Statue of Liberty National Monument, created in increments by three American presidents (beginning with Calvin Coolidge in 1924) using their authority under the Antiquities Act. The National Park Service administers it, but it doesnt belong to that agency. It belongs to a schoolteacher in Vermont, a coal miner in West Virginia, a waitress in Las Vegas, a tattooist in San Francisco, and to you, and to me, and to every other American citizen.

title: Its Time to Set Broadway Free
description: WASHINGTON  On a recent visit to New York, traversing Times Square felt like running a gantlet. Sure, the cars are gone, thanks to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, whose administration began prohibiting traffic on several blocks of Broadway in 2009 to create a vast plaza. But in short order, the vehicles seem to have been replaced with Minnies and Mickeys, Elmos and SpongeBobs and half-naked or flag-painted buskers.

title: Health Care Under Donald Trump
description: Readers discuss the challenges the G.O.P. will face with its promise to replace Obamacare.

title: Canadas $7 Billion Dam Tests the Limits of State Power
description: BEAR FLAT, British Columbia  Rugged, remote and prized for its rare microclimate, the Peace River Valley in northeastern British Columbia is an agricultural oasis in northern Canada. Alfalfa, watermelon and barley fields sprawl across a landscape flecked by caribou tracks and seasonal trappers huts, which reflect the role indigenous peoples have played in this fertile land for more than 10,000 years.

title: A Young Hockey Star in Minnesota
description: Casey Mittelstadt, part of a long line of hockey stars at Eden Prairie High School, hopes to help his team capture the state championship this year after coming close the past two seasons.

title: Eventually, the N.H.L., but First, the Minnesota State Title
description: For several weeks in the spring, a high school junior named Casey Mittelstadt contemplated where he would play hockey the next year. He considered graduating high school early and enrolling at the University of Minnesota. He thought about playing for the Green Bay Gamblers of the United States Hockey League. Or he could continue to compete for Eden Prairie High School in suburban Minneapolis.

title: To Age Is a Sin: In Blunt Speech, Madonna Confronts Bias in Various Forms
description: In the world of pop music, women are enjoying a moment of dominance. Beyonc, with her towering album and short film Lemonade, rewrote the playbook (again) in April. Adeles album 25 has soared since its release about a year ago, selling more than 10 million copies in the United States alone.

title: Rex Tillerson, Exxon Chief, Is Expected to Be Pick for Secretary of State
description: WASHINGTON  Rex W. Tillerson, the chief executive of Exxon Mobil, whose extensive deal-making for the energy giant has plunged him into global politics from Yemen to Russia, is expected to be offered the secretary of state post this weekend by President-elect Donald J. Trump, according to two people close to Mr. Trumps transition team.

title: Blasts Near Stadium in Istanbul
description: A pair of explosions occurred outside a soccer stadium in Istanbul on Saturday night. Two explosions in Istanbul killed dozens and wounded more than a hundred, and officials said police officers appeared to have been targeted.

title: ISIS Close to Recapturing Palmyra From Syrian Forces
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Islamic State fighters appeared close to retaking Palmyra, Syria, on Saturday, just nine months after Syrian government forces drove them from the desert city, where they had terrorized residents and blown up irreplaceable ancient monuments.

title: Holocaust Survivors Score Victory in Reclaiming Stolen Art
description: WASHINGTON  A group of Holocaust survivors and their families notched a crucial victory on Friday, as Congress approved legislation that would make it easier to reclaim art confiscated during World War II.

title: In Istanbul, 38 Killed in 2 Blasts Possibly Targeting Police Officers
description: ISTANBUL  Thirty-eight people were killed and 136 were wounded here on Saturday in two explosions, and officials said one of them was a car bomb outside a stadium that targeted police officers on duty for a soccer game.

title: As Turkey Cracks Down, Kurdish Mayors Pack Bags for Jail
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey  When Kurdish officials here in Diyarbakir, the biggest Kurdish city in the world, say theyve been unavoidably detained, it is not just an excuse for lateness.

title: Retronyms
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Were living in the past today, and thats not a bad thing. Sometimes its good to take a trip down memory lane, to gambol through what was, to traipse among the lilies of yesteryear.

title: Bob Dylan Sends Warm Words but Skips Nobel Prize Ceremonies
description: For Bob Dylan, the nagging question of whether his songs qualify as literature was settled for good on Saturday at the Nobel Prize ceremony in Stockholm  and his presence was not required to make the case.

title: Bob Dylans Nobel Prize Acceptance Speech
description: Good evening, everyone. I extend my warmest greetings to the members of the Swedish Academy and to all of the other distinguished guests in attendance tonight.

title: Army Triumphs at Last, Ending Navys 14-Game Streak in Rivalry
description: BALTIMORE  Tradition at the Army-Navy game calls for each teams players, at the games end, to stand in front of their fellow students and sing their alma mater, with the winning team singing second. On Saturday, for the first time since December 2001, Army sang after Navy did.

title: Louisville Quarterback Lamar Jackson Wins the Heisman Trophy
description: Fifteen months ago, Louisville quarterback Lamar Jackson began his college career in the least award-worthy way possible.

title: Carmelo Anthony and Phil Jackson Meet to Clear the Air
description: Carmelo Anthony and Phil Jackson met on Saturday in an effort to smooth over tension created last week when Jackson, the Knicks president, criticized Anthony in an interview with CBS Sports Network for sometimes holding on to the ball for too long during games.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I dont believe in aliens, but if you see enough articles about aliens visiting Earth, you start to think Who knows, maybe the government is hiding something.

title: Samantha Zins, Logan Lowe
description: Samantha Robin Zins, the daughter of Patricia Corren Zins and Dr. Jonathan H. Zins of Westport, Conn., was married Dec. 10 to Logan Stewart Lowe, a son of Lauren Silbert Lowe and Dr. Franklin C. Lowe of Manhattan. Rabbi Robert N. Levine officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

title: Christen Young, Bradley Lipton
description: Christen Linke Young, the daughter of Hawley K. Linke and Anthony P. Young of Columbus, Ohio, was married Dec. 10 to Bradley Scott Lipton, the son of Dr. Carol Miller Lipton and William J. Lipton of New Canaan, Conn. Judge John D. Bates of the United States District Court for the District of Columbia, for whom the groom was a law clerk from 2011-12, officiated at the North Hall at Eastern Market, an event space in Washington.

title: Claudia Pepe, Jake La Sala
description: Claudia Catherine Pepe and George La Sala were married Dec. 10 at the Church of St. Dominic in Oyster Bay, N.Y. Msgr. John Martin performed the ceremony with the Rev. Kevin Smith, another Roman Catholic priest.

title: Shari Sckolnick, Brent Teitel
description: Shari Debra Sckolnick, a daughter of Carol J. Sckolnick and Dr. Neal A. Sckolnick of Hewlett Harbor, N.Y., was married Dec. 10 to Brent Lloyd Teitel, the son of Cheryl H. Teitel and Michael H. Teitel of East Meadow, N.Y. Rabbi Andrew Warmflash officiated at the Pine Hollow Country Club in East Norwich, N.Y.

title: Corrections: December 11, 2016
description: THE ARTS

title: Melissa Schwartz, Gregory Nemeth
description: Melissa Ashley Schwartz, the daughter of Janet V. Schwartz and Stephen J. Schwartz of Manhattan, was married Dec. 10 in Brooklyn to Gregory Robert Nemeth, the son of Laura Nemeth of Dix Hills, N.Y., and Leonard E. Nemeth of Charlotte, N.C. Neil Assur, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Brooklyn Winery.

title: Marni Golden, Michael Shepard
description: Marni Ann Golden and Michael Scott Shepard were married Dec. 10 at Gurneys Resort in Montauk, N.Y. Jesse Golden, the brides brother, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Allison Berger, Evan Couri
description: Allison Sternberg Berger, a daughter of Susan Berger Kabaker of Glencoe, Ill., and Richard C. Berger of Glenview, Ill., was married Dec. 10 to Evan Brett Couri, a son of Maria T. Couri of New Milford, N.J., and Ronald J. Couri of Tenafly, N.J. Rabbi Steven Stark Lowenstein officiated at the Drake Hotel in Chicago.

title: Marissa Solomon, Jacob Sutker
description: Marissa Erin Solomon, the daughter of Diane L. Solomon and Craig H. Solomon of Manhattan, was married Dec. 10 to Jacob Ian Sutker, a son of Deborah E. Klatskin and Dr. Burton Sutker of Mountain Lakes, N.J. Rabbi Elliot Cosgrove officiated with Cantor Azi Schwartz at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: Talia Epstein, Jonathan Gersch
description: Talia Zoe Epstein and Jonathan David Gersch were married by Rabbi Jason Klein on Dec. 10 at Guastavinos, an event space in New York.

title: Roger Jordan Jr., Jason Chenoweth
description: Roger Percy Jordan Jr. and Robert Jason Chenoweth were married Dec. 6 at the Blackstone Hotel in Chicago. Susan Miller, a friend of the couple who was ordained by First Nation Ministry for the occasion, officiated.

title: With Uncertainties Roiling Washington and Seoul, What Next for North Korea?
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Since October, when the corruption scandal involving President Park Geun-hye of South Korea first erupted, North Korea has been uncharacteristically restrained.

title: Samantha Slater, Justin Meservie
description: Samantha Ariel Slater and Justin Ross Meservie are to be married Dec. 11 at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y. Rabbi Rafi Rank is to officiate.

title: Pavel Loparev, Francisco Bustamante
description: Pavel Loparev and Francisco Bustamante were married Dec. 10 at the Odeon, a restaurant in Manhattan. Robert R. Beard, a Universal Life minister and friend of the couple, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Gagnon, Rahul Phalnikar
description: Elizabeth Cunningham Gagnon and Rahul Phalnikar were married Dec. 10 at the Four Seasons Hotel in New York. The Rev. Beverly Bartlett, a Presbyterian minister, officiated. On Dec. 24, they are to have a Hindu ceremony at the JW Marriott Hotel in Pune, India, where Chitale Guruji is to officiate.

title: Emily Friedman, Ed Cohen
description: Emily Claire Friedman, a daughter of Gillian Friedman and Paul Friedman of North Salem, N.Y., was married Dec. 10 to Ed Cohen, a son of Judith F. Cohen and E. Judd Cohen of Greenwich, Conn. Rabbi Sarah Reines officiated at the Current at Chelsea Piers, an event space in New York.

title: Whitney Keefe, David Snider
description: Dr. Whitney Margaret Keefe, a daughter of Hillary R. Mankin-Kufe and Dr. Donald W. Kufe of Wellesley, Mass., was married Dec. 10 to David Andrew Snider, a son of Jody B. Snider and Andrew E. Snider of Boston. Laurie L. Schaffran, a friend of the grooms family who was ordained by American Marriage Ministries for the occasion, officiated at the New York Public Librarys main branch.

title: Louisiana Republican Wins Final U.S. Senate Seat in Runoff
description: BATON ROUGE, La.  Bringing a wildly unpredictable election cycle to an unsurprising close, Louisiana voters on Saturday elected John Neely Kennedy, the state treasurer, to the Senate, giving Republicans a final 52-48 advantage over the Democrats.

title: Seattle Sounders Win M.L.S. Cup Over Toronto F.C. in a Shootout
description: TORONTO  In one of the more remarkable turnarounds in M.L.S. history, the Seattle Sounders won their first M.L.S. Cup on Saturday night, defeating Toronto F.C., 5-4, in a penalty shootout after 120 minutes of scoreless play in an intense and frigid setting.

title: Whats on TV Sunday: Frozen and The Dick Van Dyke Show  Now in Living Color!
description: Frozen, the Disney blockbuster  with its anthem of empowerment, Let It Go  arrives on network television. The Dick Van Dyke Show comes alive in color. And Benedict Cumberbatch and Tom Sturridge play Shakespeares kings in The Hollow Crown.

title: Homes That Sold for $1.5 Million and Up
description: 4 Taylor Court, Lattingtown

title: The Oakland Fire: What We Know About the Warehouse Owner
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  New York Times reporters are investigating the devastating fire that killed 36 people this month at a warehouse called the Ghost Ship in Oakland, Calif. Were also doing something new: providing regular updates on our findings. Do you have information, advice or feedback? Send email to oaklandfire@nytimes.com.

title: Donald Trump, Russia, Dylann Roof: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here are the weeks top stories, and a look ahead.

title: Stroll in the Park With Ai Weiwei
description: Ai Weiwei, the acclaimed Chinese artist, takes us on a walk through his old stomping ground in Tompkins Square Park. Four exhibitions of his work are currently in New York.

title: Attack on Coptic Cathedral in Cairo Kills Dozens
description: CAIRO  A bomb ripped through a section reserved for women at Cairos main Coptic cathedral during Sunday morning Mass, killing at least 25 people and wounding 49, mostly women and children, Egyptian state media said.

title: Trump Links C.I.A. Reports on Russia to Democrats Shame Over Election
description: WASHINGTON  President-elect Donald J. Trump said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that he did not believe American intelligence assessments that Russia had intervened to help his candidacy, casting blame for the reports on Democrats, who he said were embarrassed about losing to him.

title: In a Smoky Haze, Turks Cling to Their Cigarettes
description: ISTANBUL  The Italians have a saying for it: Fuma come un turco, meaning, He smokes like a Turk.

title: A Motel Reopens, but Now Guests Must Pay for the Whole Night
description: Everything you need to know about the Staten Island Motor Lodge is right there on a large sign in the parking lot: Prostitution on This Property is Strictly Prohibited and Will Be Reported to Local Law Enforcement Authorities.

title: Dreams That a Sister Can Have the Fullest Life Possible
description: In the rare instances that Shareen Williams can treat her younger sister to something special, like a nail salon pampering for her birthday, it comes with a twinge of regret.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Iran and Boeing Sign $16.6 Billion Deal on Sale of 80 Aircraft
description: TEHRAN  Iran and Boeing signed a deal for the sale of 80 airplanes on Sunday, five weeks before the inauguration of President-elect Donald J. Trump, whose Republican supporters in Congress have tried to block any aircraft sales to Iran.

title: The Downward Slide of the Seesaw
description: The two young brothers seesawed in Riverside Park recently, testing and tormenting each other, absorbed in a playground ritual familiar to generations of children.

title: Paolo Gentiloni, Italys Foreign Minister, Will Try to Form a New Government
description: ROME  Italys foreign minister, Paolo Gentiloni, accepted a presidential mandate on Sunday to try to form a new government, hoping to lead Italy out of a political crisis that ensued with the resignation of Matteo Renzi as prime minister.

title: In Search of a Coquito Like Abuela Used to Make
description: Some people will go anywhere in search of the perfect holiday drink where a single taste,  la Proust, summons warm memories of Christmases past. For Puerto Ricans celebrating with coquito, a fortified coconut eggnog, their quest took them this month to The South of France.

title: Buoyed by Donald Trump Win, Jerusalem Mayor Hopes to Get U.S. Embassy
description: The mayor of Jerusalem says that he is optimistic that once Donald J. Trump becomes president, the United States will quickly move its embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to his contested ancient city, a step every other American administration has resisted to the annoyance of many Israeli Jews.

title: Madonna and Hillary: Witch and Nasty Woman as Sisters in Arms
description: I was called a whore and a witch, Madonna said on Friday in a searing speech about the sexism and bullying that women face in the music industry and the culture at large.

title: Inquiry Into Racial Bias in New York Prisons Is Big Job for Small Team
description: Just hours after revelations of pervasive racial bias by prison guards in New York State were published last week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo ordered a statewide inquiry.

title: N.F.L.: Heres How the Playoff Picture Looks After Week 14
description: Giants to Cowboys: Not yet.

title: Aleppo, Donald Trump, Istanbul: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: An Artistic Discovery Makes a Curators Heart Pound
description: PARIS  Its an auctioneers jackpot dream. A man walks in off the street, opens a portfolio of drawings, and there, mixed in with the jumble of routine low-value items, is a long-lost work by Leonardo da Vinci.

title: Small Investors Join Chinas Tycoons in Sending Money Abroad
description: Adam Dahill saw promise in the three-story brownstone on a quiet Bedford-Stuyvesant street, despite its weather-beaten facade, crumbling front steps and broken windows. But he needed nearly $1.3 million to buy it and turn it into the sort of Brooklyn dream home for which the citys lawyers and bankers pay big money.

title: Trump Suggests Using Bedrock China Policy as Bargaining Chip
description: WASHINGTON  President-elect Donald J. Trump, defending his recent phone call with Taiwans president, asserted in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the United States was not bound by the One China policy, the 44-year diplomatic understanding that underpins Americas relationship with its biggest rival.

title: La La Land Sizzles in Limited Release in North America
description: LOS ANGELES  It was a weekend of nice and naughty at the box office, with two buoyant musicals, Moana and La La Land, turning in big results alongside the decidedly raunchy Office Christmas Party.

title: My First Day in America: Seeing Truman
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Tony Romos Star Is Eclipsed by Another Feel-Good Story
description: FRISCO, Tex.  The Dallas Cowboys new headquarters is sparkly and showy and so Texas-over-the-top that it makes the teams longtime base of operations  in Irving, about 20 miles southwest of here  look like your grandparents wood-paneled rec room. The complex is like an airy, marbled museum, with reminders, maybe every 10 steps, that the Cowboys once were a dynasty: Super Bowl rings, Super Bowl trophies and hagiographic displays of all five of the franchises Super Bowl victories.

title: Review: Normal Looks Into the Abyss and Finds the Future
description: Some writers have been thinking about the future for so long that now it is the future. Warren Ellis, the author of a smart, tight, occasionally tiresome new novel called Normal, has been at work on the subject since the early 1990s and may have decided it was time to offer a sly acknowledgment of his own longevity: The book is about a sanitarium full of futurologists in various states of nervous breakdown.

title: Nicholas Serota Wins Bard Curatorial Award
description: Nicholas Serota, the soon-to-be departing director of the Tate museums in Britain, is to receive the 2017 Audrey Irmas Award for Curatorial Excellence.

title: Russias Hand in Americas Election
description: Its not hard to see why Russia would have been tempted to tip the scales in Americas presidential election. American defense officials have been warning about Russias capabilities and dangerous intentions, calling Moscow the gravest threat to the United States.

title: Kurdish Militant Group Claims Responsibility for Deadly Istanbul Bombing
description: ISTANBUL  A Kurdish militant group claimed responsibility on Sunday for a double bombing that killed 39 people and wounded 154 outside a soccer stadium in the heart of Istanbul the night before.

title: Review: Joffrey Ballets New Nutcracker Leaves Some Tradition Behind
description: CHICAGO  The Nutcracker is traditionally set in Nuremberg, Germany, in the early 19th century. But across America, which presents far more productions of this ballet than any other country, the story is often transposed to the city in which its being performed. From New London, Conn., to Nashville, audiences can watch their local Nutcracker with civic pride; and certainly these American adaptations appeal to the tourist in me.

title: Review: Jingle Ball Tour Shows Radio Still Rocks
description: Charlie Puth sauntered onto the Madison Square Garden stage Friday night with arms up and out, in a sort of parabola, as if harvesting the adulation being fired at him from the crowd like so many tiny pebbles.

title: The New Reality of TV: All Trump, All the Time
description: President-elect Donald J. Trump recently appeared at a Carrier furnace factory in Indiana and explained why he was there, having worked out a deal to keep some of that companys jobs from moving to Mexico.

title: Standing Up to a Strongman
description: MANILA  Dusk set silver-gray over the crowd gathered in a park here on Nov. 25, but the banners and placards could still be clearly seen. Homemade, cardboard, some laminated with packing tape to protect them from the rain, the signs expressed the rage of thousands of young Filipinos rallying against the recent, clandestine burial of the dictator Ferdinand Marcos in the Cemetery of Heroes.

title: Communication Problem
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Todays theme by Mark McClain brought to mind the biblical story of the Tower of Babel. Six different languages come at each other and none of them understand a word the other is saying because of a very common issue.

title: How Islam Can Fight the Patriarchy
description: ISTANBUL  On Nov. 17, members of Parliament from Turkeys ruling Justice and Development Party, or A.K.P., proposed a bill that seemed bizarre, even in the context of Turkey, where every week seems to bring a new, shocking outrage. The bill called for people who had sexually abused underage girls before Nov. 16 to avoid punishment if the abuser agreed to marry his victim.

title: Heng on Trumps Relationship With China
description: Donald Trumps comments on Chinas trade and military policies have fanned questions about whether he wants to reset the relationship with Beijing more fundamentally.

title: Rex Tillerson, an Aggressive Dealmaker Whose Ties With Russia May Prompt Scrutiny
description: HOUSTON  Twenty years ago, as Rex W. Tillerson was rising through the ranks at Exxon, he was charged with negotiating with the government of Yemen to build a natural gas export plant. The talks got bogged down over Yemens insistence that it have veto power over important business decisions.

title: I.M.F. Chief Heads to Trial; Fed Is Expected to Raise Rate
description: Heres a look at whats coming up the week.

title: Could You Patent the Sun?
description: Decades after Dr. Jonas Salk opposed patenting the polio vaccine, the pharmaceutical industry has changed. What does that mean for the development of innovative drugs and for people whose lives depend on them?

title: Lives and Profits in the Balance: The High Stakes of Medical Patents
description: The West Wing, Aaron Sorkins television series about a fictional White House, had a knack for crisply summarizing complex real-life issues. In an episode from 2000, pharmaceutical executives and leaders of an AIDS-plagued African country are summoned to the White House. The purpose is to see if reluctant businessmen can be persuaded to sell the Africans desperately needed drugs at a modest price.

title: Review: Kyle Abrahams Untitled America Helps Open Alvin Ailey Season
description: Now more than ever: The phrase is all over the publicity for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters season at City Center this year. Its easy to imagine why the inspiration and solace for which this company is known might be newly relevant, newly needed. Near the start of Revelations, the work this troupe has danced in most of its performances for decades, torqued bodies express the pain of the oppressed to the sung words there is trouble all over this world. At the end, those bodies rock in joyful redemption.

title: Katie Ledeckys Coach Moves On From His Masterpiece
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  The banner that greeted the Nations Capital Swim Club coach, Bruce Gemmell, at the natatorium on the University of Maryland campus gave him a start. It announced that his son, Andrew, a 2012 Olympian, and his most famous swimmer, Katie Ledecky, would be signing autographs during the age-group meet that Nations Capital annually hosts.

title: Critics Choice Awards Red Carpet
description: The Critics Choice Awards took place in Los Angeles on Sunday. See what nominees like Viola Davis, Michelle Williams and more wore.

title: Designing a Safer Battery for Smartphones (That Wont Catch Fire)
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Mike Zimmerman likes to shock his guests by using a hammer to drive a nail through a solid polymer lithium metal battery.

title: With Flood of Urbanites, a Canadian Hippie Haven Tries to Keep Its Mellow
description: NELSON, British Columbia  Marijuana, Vietnam War draft dodgers and artists gave Nelson its tree-hugging, bohemian soul.

title: Google Effect Rubs Off on Schools in One Rural Oklahoma Town
description: PRYOR, Okla.  Students at Pryor High School study robotics. Elementary schools have basic computer programming classes using free laptops, online collaboration software and Wi-Fi spread across this small town in Oklahomas Green Country.

title: The Bane of the N.B.A. Coach: The In-Game Interview
description: The concept of in-game interviews with N.B.A. coaches was still fairly new when Doris Burke, a respected sideline reporter and broadcaster for ESPN, had an unfortunate experience.

title: New Mothers Derailed by Drugs Find Support in New Hampshire Home
description: ROCHESTER, N.H.  The young women, soon to be mothers, gathered around a big kitchen table, chatting excitedly about due dates and baby names and even morning sickness.

title: Ken Hechler, West Virginia Populist and Coal Miners Champion, Dies at 102
description: Ken Hechler, a leading voice for national coal-mining reforms during his nine terms in the House of Representatives and a colorful presence in West Virginia politics for decades, died on Saturday at his home in Romney, W.Va. He was 102 and had been the oldest living former member of Congress.

title: More Than Cookie Sellers: The Girl Scouts Buff Their Image
description: The Girl Scouts want you to know theres more to them than cookies.

title: Hofstra Encounters Drawbacks to Playing Kentucky, Besides the Loss
description: Last month, the night before his team played at Columbia, Hofstras basketball coach, Joe Mihalich, walked into the locker room after practice and found his team watching Kentucky pummel Arizona State in a game the Wildcats eventually won by 46 points.

title: In Trump Era, Uncompromising TV News Should Be the Norm, Not the Exception
description: Too often television news, especially on cable, serves as a megaphone for politicians who use it to forward lies and propaganda while so effortlessly ignoring questions theyre supposedly there to answer.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

description: 8:30 p.m. Eastern, ESPN Line: Patriots by 7

title: Center-Left Party Poised to Regain Power in Romania
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Romanian voters appeared to return the center-left Social Democratic Party to power in parliamentary elections on Sunday, a year after large protests in Bucharest over a deadly nightclub fire led to the resignation of the partys previous government.

title: C.I.A. Judgment on Russia Built on Swell of Evidence
description: WASHINGTON  American spy and law enforcement agencies were united in the belief, in the weeks before the presidential election, that the Russian government had deployed computer hackers to sow chaos during the campaign. But they had conflicting views about the specific goals of the subterfuge.

description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Im an educated nurse who knows the system, and I couldnt navigate it. I thought, What is everyone else doing? And it blew my mind when I realized what everyone else was doing, which was dying.

title: Boeing Speaks in Trump Terms on Iran Deal: Its About Jobs
description: Boeing announced a $16.6 billion deal on Sunday to sell planes to Iran, which for decades had been economically blacklisted by the United States. The company instead chose to emphasize how many jobs the sale would support.

title: Abortion Foes, Emboldened by Trump, Promise Onslaught of Tough Restrictions
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Christina Hagan, the youngest woman in the Ohio Legislature, received a surprise last week. The toughest piece of abortion legislation in the country  a bill she had championed for years  suddenly passed.

title: Bill English Is Chosen as New Zealands Prime Minister
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Bill English, a veteran conservative politician, became New Zealands 39th prime minister on Monday after the governing National Party chose him to succeed John Key, whose resignation a week ago took New Zealand by surprise.

title: An Organization Paves a Path Out of Rikers Island and Into the Job Market
description: At 19, Michael Vanleuvan was in jail at Rikers Island awaiting sentencing for armed robbery when he found himself listening with other inmates to a retired business executive talk about a program that could help them when they got out.

title: Review: In Transit Goes on an a Cappella Ride
description: Every now and then, as yet another peppy clich prances across the stage of the Circle in the Square Theater, you may pause to ponder the pioneering achievement of In Transit, the singing portrait of New York City subway travelers, which opened on Sunday night. After all, what youre listening to often gleams with the blended polyphony of a good-size band.

title: Antti Raantas Hot Hand in Goal Steers Rangers to Shutout of Devils
description: No more than three or four Rangers fans joined in a chant for goaltender Antti Raanta after his first big save Sunday against the Devils  as if the rest of the crowd were a little afraid to hurt the feelings of the $9.5-million-a-year star goalie plopped on the bench, Henrik Lundqvist.

title: The Affair Season 3, Episode 4: Is Alison O.K.?
description: Daddy! Can I watch a show? Those were the first words of Sundays episode of The Affair, a clarion call from young Joanie (about to turn 5) that woke up her father, Cole, and her stepmother, Luisa. Little did Joanie know that Daddy was enjoying a show of his own: a steamy-tender dream of making love with her mother and his ex-wife, Alison.

title: Macedonian Election With Chance to Break Deadlock Ends in Virtual Tie
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  Macedonias ruling party and its largest opposition party both declared victory on Sunday night in parliamentary elections that were supposed to end a two-year political deadlock but appear to have merely extended it.

title: Giants End Cowboys 11-Game Winning Streak and Sweep Season Series
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants fans began booing early in the third quarter of their teams game with the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday night.

description: Tell us about your experiences with pretrial diversion.

description: KHAZER CAMP, Iraq  By the time the jihadists had finished, not even a womans eyes were legal. Showing them was a punishable offense.
