description: The author of The Genius of Judaism believes the current political situation in the United States is best illuminated by Philip Roths The Plot Against America.

title: A New Year, and New Duds, for the Vienna Philharmonic
description: Few people outside wedding parties or royal families concern themselves much these days with when to wear morning suits and when evening wear is called for. One group that has long preserved the distinction, the Vienna Philharmonic, announced on Thursday that it was getting its first change of clothes in decades  suits that can be worn by day or night with small variations.

title: New Cease-Fire Begins in Syria, but Violations Are Reported Within Hours
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A cease-fire between Syrias government and the weakened rebel forces arrayed against it took effect early Friday, but within hours, violations were reported.

title: China Says 5 Killed in Attack at Communist Party Office in Xinjiang
description: BEIJING  Five people were killed in a clash at a branch of the Communist Party in the western Chinese region of Xinjiang, the state news media reported on Thursday.

title: Inside the Actors Dream Studio
description: The actors nightmare is much like the anxiety dreams experienced by many of us who have never stepped onstage.

title: California Today: With New Laws, What Will Change in 2017?
description: Good morning.

title: As Interest Grows in Great Walls, an Ancient Chinese Fortress Beckons
description: JIAYUGUAN, China  The fortress stands watch in a parched land with snow-encrusted mountains beyond, a lone rook on the empty chessboard of western Chinas Gobi Desert.

title: Why Saudi Arabia Is Likely to Postpone a Huge Oil Company I.P.O.
description: Saudi Arabias oil producer, Saudi Aramco, is its crown jewel. And jewels ought not to be given away too freely.

title: We Need to Talk About Kanye
description: This year has been especially heavy with untimely popular culture deaths. In the past week, George Michael and Carrie Fisher joined that tally. Neither was entirely comfortable with fame, even though Ms. Fisher, as the daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher, was born with fame virtually in her bloodstream. Her ambivalence always seemed healthy even when she herself was not. Their deaths are an occasion to think about the toll fame takes on a person, not only on the dead but also on the living. What if that person is Kanye West?

title: Russia Finds No Signs of Explosion in Black Sea Plane Crash
description: MOSCOW  Russian investigators said on Thursday that they had found no evidence that an explosion occurred aboard a Russian military plane that crashed into the Black Sea, killing all 92 passengers and crew, but that they had not ruled out the possibility of a terrorist attack.

title: Paper Calendars Endure Despite the Digital Age
description: With the years end comes the ritual of many households and offices: getting new appointment books, planners or calendars to hang on walls or put on desks.

title: The Best Styles Photography of 2016
description: This year, our photographers captured subjects of all kinds: famous and little-known, athletic and political, human and canine. Here are our favorite shots from their assignments.

title: Praise for Kerrys Israel Speech in Arab World, but Shrugs, Too
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Secretary of State John Kerrys harsh words for Israel echoed across the Arab world on Thursday, earning praise from some governments long frustrated with American support for the Jewish state while eliciting shrugs from others who believe the tough talk was too little, too late.

title: Multimediated Lives: An Erudite Tour of Digital Culture
description: THE FOUR-DIMENSIONAL HUMANWays of Being in the Digital WorldBy Laurence Scott248 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. Paper, $16.95.

title: For Better or Worse: New Books Forecast the Next Technologies
description: THE SIGNALS ARE TALKINGWhy Todays Fringe Is Tomorrows MainstreamBy Amy Webb322 pp. PublicAffairs. $27.99.

title: Fantasy Football: Players to Start in Week 17
description: The Sablich brothers have provided award-winning fantasy football advice for The New York Times since 2010. See their weekly player rankings and visit 5thDownFantasy.com for more fantasy analysis. You can also ask them questions through their Twitter account, @5thdownfantasy.

title: Constance Wu, Brian Tyree Henry and David Harbour Agree on the Best TV of 2016
description: We asked some of this years notable authors, actors and showrunners about the TV they enjoyed most in 2016. Come back to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site, to read them all.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Kennedy and Trumbo

title: What a Sensory Isolation Tank Taught Me About My Brain
description: Take off your clothes, step into the pod and shut the top. And be really careful not to get any of the salt in your eyes. Those were the instructions I was given recently just before I entered a sensory isolation tank in Seattle. Finally, I would have my chance to see what it would be like to be a brain in a jar.

title: First, a Mixtape. Then a Romance.
description: Just how music-obsessed is Hillary Kerr, the 37-year-old founder of a lifestyle-focused digital media company in Los Angeles? She can tell you what song was playing five years ago on the jukebox at the bar where she somewhat randomly met the man who became her husband. It was These Days, the version sung by Nico, the German singer-songwriter made famous by Andy Warhol and the Velvet Underground.

title: Help for Australias Coal Workers
description: BRISBANE, Australia  Australians got coal for Christmas.

title: Donald Trump, After Dismissing Hacking, Agrees to an Intelligence Briefing
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  President-elect Donald J. Trump edged away on Thursday from his dismissive stance on American assessments of Russian hacking, saying he would meet with intelligence officials next week to be updated on the facts after the Obama administration announced sanctions against Moscow.

title: How to Turn Off a Windows Live Tile
description: Q. Although its fairly new, the battery on my Windows 10 laptop seems to drain quickly. I suspect the live tiles in the Start menu have something to do with that. I like the weather and news updates, but is there a way to shut down the tiles I dont care about to save some power?

title: Germany Releases Tunisian Held in Connection With Berlin Attack
description: BERLIN  The German authorities released a 40-year-old Tunisian man on Thursday who had been detained a day earlier as a possible accomplice in the truck attack on a Berlin Christmas market, a spokeswoman for the public prosecutor general said.

title: The Washington Huskies Biggest Trick? It Might Be Their Reputation
description: ATLANTA  If Jimi Hendrix had held a news conference before a concert, a reporter would probably have asked him about guitar solos. In the same way, it only made sense that when Washington Coach Chris Petersen held court this week ahead of the Huskies matchup Saturday against No. 1 Alabama in the College Football Playoff semifinals, someone brought up trick plays.

title: Why Netanyahu Will Miss Obama
description: Even before President Obamas decision last week to abstain on a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning Israeli settlements, it was safe to assume that the Israeli government was eagerly awaiting his departure. In the eyes of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Mr. Obama  who skipped Israel on his first trip to the Middle East and later undertook secret nuclear talks with Iran  seemed unable to appreciate the depth of Israels security needs or the difficulties of Mr. Netanyahus domestic politics.

title: What Youll Be Reading in 2017
description: Last year in this space I looked ahead to 16 anticipated books being published in 2016. This year Ill list 17. Pray for me that Im not writing this column in 2055.

title: Daily Report: Tech Resolutions for 2017
description: With 2016 nearly at an end, its time to make some New Years resolutions. To best prepare, Brian X. Chen, the New York Timess personal technology writer, suggests making tech resolutions, as well.

title: Yeah, Life Is Very Sunny for Kaitlin Olson
description: Many funny actors will go an entire career without landing a lead role in a television sitcom. Meanwhile, Kaitlin Olson is holding down two of them simultaneously: Since 2005, she has played the beleaguered bartender Sweet Dee on Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia, the proudly unrefined ensemble comedy that begins its 12th season on Wednesday, Jan. 4, on FXX.

title: Facebooks Safety Check, Now Automated, Turns a Firecracker Into an Explosion
description: Since 2014, Facebooks Safety Check feature has allowed people in areas stricken by natural disasters and terror attacks to swiftly tell their friends that theyre unharmed. On Tuesday, it was activated for The Explosion in Bangkok, Thailand.

title: August Wilsons Jitney at Manhattan Theater Club
description: August Wilson was a Broadway playwright when few others were. In the final decades of last century, when Wilson towered over the contemporary stage, even our finest writers couldnt expect that every one of their new plays would appear in a commercial theater increasingly dominated by musicals and classic revivals.

title: Ronda Rousey Is Returning to the U.F.C. Cage. Can She Dominate Again?
description: When the seemingly unbeatable Ronda Rousey lost her Ultimate Fighting Championship title to Holly Holm in November 2015, it was an epic shock. It also seemed to set up the opportunity for a quick comeback story.

title: A Gut Makeover for the New Year
description: If youre making resolutions for a healthier new year, consider a gut makeover. Refashioning the community of bacteria and other microbes living in your intestinal tract, collectively known as the gut microbiome, could be a good long-term investment in your health.

title: Documents Open Curtain on Boardroom Drama at Valeant
description: Its rare to get a peek behind the corporate curtain and to catch a glimpse of the real-time deterioration of the relationship between an activist investor and the chief executive he had long supported.

title: How Octopuses Are Like Aliens
description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Would-Be Carmakers Tap the Wisdom, and Dollars, of Crowds
description: AFTER Ford Motor came close to bankruptcy in the late 1970s, the company decided to bet the store on what was then a radical new design: what would come to be known as the Ford Taurus.

title: Driven | 2017 Acura MDX
description: The three-row Acura MDX is the right size for slinging through urban streets in rewarding fashion. Now, how about a little pizazz in the cabin?

title: The 2017 Acura MDX Is the Whole Package, Minus a Frill or Two
description: Automotive product planners have a tough job. They wrestle with what to put in or leave out in order to deliver a profitable vehicle that appeals to the masses.

title: The Story Behind a Well-Timed Photo of Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher
description: At 26, Lawrence Schiller was already taking pictures of some of the biggest celebrities in the world.

title: Poland Buys Czartoryski Family Art Collection
description: WARSAW  A significant private art collection that includes a rare painting by Leonardo da Vinci, as well as works by Rembrandt and Renoir, will be owned by the Polish government under an agreement signed Thursday with the family foundation that has administered the collection since its inception.

title: Top Travel Tips of 2016
description: 1. Is Tuesday really the best day to buy plane tickets? Nope. There are too many variables at play for there to be a universally ideal day to buy an airline ticket.

title: Differing Outlooks as the Trump Presidency Nears
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Grinch Ended Up in Court!
description: The Broadway playwright Matthew Lombardo has sued the owner of copyrights for Dr. Seusss works, arguing that his new play does not infringe on the classic How the Grinch Stole Christmas!

title: The Two-State Solution: What It Is and Why It Hasnt Happened
description: Secretary of State John Kerry on Wednesday joined a growing chorus warning that the so-called two-state solution, which he called the only way to achieve a just and lasting peace between Israelis and Palestinians, could be on the verge of permanent collapse.

title: The Rift Between the U.S. and Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: I Got My Dog Through The New York Times
description: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times.

title: Searching for the Human Factor in Deadly Avalanches
description: Every year, about 30 Americans die in avalanches, with an additional 110 deaths in Canada and Europe. Skiers and snowmobilers account for the vast majority of these deaths.

title: Obama Strikes Back at Russia for Election Hacking
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama struck back at Russia on Thursday for its efforts to influence the 2016 election, ejecting 35 suspected Russian intelligence operatives from the United States and imposing sanctions on Russias two leading intelligence services.

title: How Russia Recruited Elite Hackers for Its Cyberwar
description: MOSCOW  Aleksandr B. Vyarya thought his job was to defend people from cyberattacks  until, he says, his government approached him with a request to do the opposite.

title: Did Debbie Reynolds Die of a Broken Heart?
description: No one can know if the actress Debbie Reynolds  who died on Wednesday, a day after her daughter, Carrie Fisher  died of a broken heart. Ms. Reynolds, 84, had suffered from several health problems in recent years, and doctors said any number of factors could have contributed to her death, possibly from a stroke.

title: Is the Recent Spike in Marriages a Trump Bump?
description: It was around 8 a.m. on a Monday when Matthew Sabato looked across the paint-splattered studio in Harlem where he lives with his partner, Pedro Silva, an artist.

title: Russia, Syria, Israel: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: G.E.s Next C.E.O. Could Come From Current Deals
description: Succession planning is a big deal at most public companies. For the first time in 124 years, General Electrics may be determined by deal making. As Jeff Immelt nears retirement, the progress of two large acquisitions in the coming year will help guide G.E.s board on who should get the top job.

title: Along Mosuls Front Line, Desperate Civilians and Dug-In Troops and Fighters
description: In the battle against the Islamic State for Mosul, Iraqs second-largest city, there is no continuous front line, but a patchwork of battlegrounds in the city and all around its edge.

title: 4 Trailers That Have Us Excited for 2017
description: A new year brings new movies, of course, but their promotion has already begun. With a full slate of films headed to the big screen in the next few months, heres a look at notable trailers.

title: Syrian Cease-Fire Announced
description: The Syrian government, backed by Russia, announced on Thursday that a cease-fire agreement with Syrian rebels and Turkey would begin Friday. Syrians have mixed feelings about the truce.

title: Oh, My Aching Head: Movies for the Soused or Now Sober
description: In the parts of the world that experience winter as winter, New Years Day is special. On a sunny cold New Years Day here in New York, the piercing light and the sharp air can serve as a metaphorical  and metaphysical  reproach, even if youre stone cold sober; its not desirable hangover weather. In the years before my domestication, my New Years Day hangover cure involved more alcohol and a trip home to New Jersey, where I and some similarly afflicted friends would gorge on regional comfort food  deep-fried hot dogs and fries all the way at Rutts Hut in Clifton, perhaps, or a cheeseburger and onion rings from the sadly departed Hearth on Route 46. Only after completing this ritual would we consider a movie, preferably something loud and empty.

title: No Leftovers for You
description: After a big holiday meal, my fianc and I watched as our hostess wrapped up the remaining turkey without offering us any to take home. We were shocked! Had the roles been reversed, we would never dream of sending guests home without enough turkey for at least a couple of sandwiches. (Its not as if there was a shortage. We watched her fill two large Tupperware containers with bird.) Was our hostess rude, or are we imposing our Midwestern code on East Coast friends?

title: Rasputin Unravels the Myths of the Mad Monk
description: From the opening pages of his colossal biography of Grigory Rasputin, the historian Douglas Smith dismantles many of the myths enshrouding the monk who exerted inordinate influence over Nicholas II and Alexandra, emperor and empress of Russia, during the twilight of the Romanov dynasty a century ago.

title: Parents and Bullying
description: To the Editor:

title: Alone in the Big City
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bathroom Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Report on Russian Hacking
description: The F.B.I. and Department of Homeland Security released a report on Thursday detailing the ways that Russia acted to influence the American election through cyberespionage.

title: Takata Said to Be Close to Deal With U.S. Over Deadly Airbags
description: The auto parts maker Takata is nearing a sweeping settlement with federal prosecutors over airbags that can violently explode, according to two people briefed on the discussions. The devices have been linked to many deaths and injuries and prompted the largest recall in automotive history.

title: A Room Where a Tinder Executive Can Reflect
description: LOS ANGELES  In a study stacked with novels and nostalgia, a casual chat may have changed internet history.

title: Military Helicopter Crash Kills Two
description: Both crew members died when an Army National Guard helicopter crashed in Texas on Wednesday during a routine training mission.

title: New York State Is Ordered to Release $69 Million for Failing Schools
description: It was an educational conundrum: If schools were being given money because they were called failing, once that label was removed could they still get the money?

title: Street-Inspired Art at the Asia Society Museum
description: Street artists often labor hastily, installing their work under the cover of night, to try to avoid detection. But the Indonesian artist and polymath Eko Nugroho will be working on his own street-inspired mural in front of visitors at the Asia Society Museum for three days, starting Saturday, Jan. 7.

title: Review: Sherlock Returns, Tracking a Smasher of Thatcher Busts
description: If Arthur Conan Doyle were writing it, he might call it The Adventure of the Changeable Detective.

title: Iggy Pop Life Class, With Guess Who as the Model
The Pitfalls of Trying to Read a Co-Workers Mind
description: As a blind man, Im often aware of false assumptions that my colleagues make about me. Sometimes their misconceptions are transparent. Other times they are unstated. Still others are imagined, projections of my own anxieties and insecurities.

title: Critics Choice: The Best and Worst Presidential Portraits
description: As a new American president prepares to take office, our co-chief art critic Holland Cotter has singled out  some of the major paintings featuring presidents past.

title: How Many Choreographers Does It Take to Create a Duet? 16
description: Starting on Tuesday, Jan. 3, the American Dance Platform will gather eight companies from around the country that have a range of influences: jazz, ballet, salsa, modern, Indian and Afro-Cuban dance. The week, curated by Alice B. Adams, of the Kennedy Center in Washington, includes events like an epic duet by 16 choreographers; a dance comparing human relations to a chess game; a tribute to cosmic energy; a satirical depiction of comic book superheroes; and evocations of water  both its grandeur and scarcity. Succeeding programs, each with two attractions, offer companies like Contra-Tiempo (Los Angeles), RAWdance (San Francisco), Ragamala Dance Company (Minneapolis), Davalois Fearon Dance (New York), Dallas Black Dance Theater and Lucky Plush Productions (Chicago). These dancers have brains in their heads as well as steps in their feet. (Through Jan. 8, Joyce Theater; joyce.org/performances.)

title: A New Take on Romeo and Juliets Ball, Balcony, Bed and Tomb
description: It might seem like impertinence, not to say blasphemy, to suggest that Shakespeare could ever be bettered. But Bartlett Sher, the director of a new production of Gounods Romo et Juliette that opens at the Metropolitan Opera on New Years Eve, is willing to go there.

title: Conjuring Musical and Colonial Ghosts
description: Theres no shortage of engravings and paintings that illustrate what Lower Manhattan looked like in colonial times. But what did it sound like? As St. Pauls Chapel continues to celebrate the 250th anniversary of its founding, an ambitious music program at Trinity Wall Street conjures sounds from the past as part of its Times Arrow festival, which begins Sunday, Jan. 1.

title: After Belt Tightening, Venture Capitalists See More Promise in 2017
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Investors who once poured money into the nations start-ups with abandon began to tighten their belts this year.

title: PWR BTTM: Traditionalists, of Glam and Drag
description: PWR BTTM, the melodic and theatrical punk duo of Liv Bruce and Ben Hopkins, are masters of presentation. Onstage and in videos, the pair allow their simple, effective songs, which often hover around two minutes, to burst with color and queerness from glam rock and drag traditions. (I Wanna Boi, from the groups 2015 debut full-length, Ugly Cherries, is a wonderful example.)

title: This Past Provides a Nice Prologue at Film Society of Lincoln Center
description: Like Janus, the Film Society of Lincoln Center is pretty adept at looking backward and forward at the same time. It begins 2017 by concluding a survey of 40 years of movies at least partly defined by their use of Steadicam shots. The series runs through Tuesday, Jan. 3, but cinephiles stirring on New Years Day will find a last seasonal gift: an indelible lineup of Paul Thomas Andersons Boogie Nights; Martin Scorseses Goodfellas; and Quentin Tarantinos Pulp Fiction.

title: Serena Williams Announces Engagement to Alexis Ohanian, Reddits Co-Founder
description: Who the Heck Is Alexis Ohanian, and Why Would Serena Williams Want to Date Him? Slate magazine asked in a headline last year.

title: Review: Dr. Feelgood: Dealer or Healer? Its Not a Simple Question
description: Accompanied by a tinkling piano and soft lighting, Dr. William Hurwitz, the subject of Eve Marsons catchily titled and infuriatingly vague documentary, Dr. Feelgood: Dealer or Healer?, faces the camera with a benign smile. For someone who has endured two criminal trials for narcotics distribution and served almost five years in prison, he seems remarkably at peace.

title: Fresh Dewdrops for New York City Ballets Nutcracker
description: In recent years, New York City Ballets corps has been a wellspring of talent, bubbling up to refresh and replenish a company already in fine fettle. The 2014 and 2015 seasons of George Balanchines The Nutcracker brought a flood of six new Sugarplum Fairies (notably Emilie Gerrity and Unity Phelan) from the corps. This December has brought new interpreters of the ballets four next most important roles: Dewdrop, Drosselmeier, the Fairys Cavalier and Marzipan.

title: Paperback Row
description: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading by editors at The New York Times.

title: Peter Voulkos, an Influential Sculptor Who Broke the Rules
description: Calling Peter Voulkos a ceramist is a bit like calling Jimi Hendrix a guitarist. The charismatic, rebellious sculptor and teacher was a genuine rock star of his medium, a trained potter who went on to violate every rule of pot-making  often before a live audience. His sculptures started out clearly enough as polite, wheel-thrown vessels but evolved into nervy and transgressive abstract paintings, looming behemoths fired in industrial-size kilns, precarious assemblages and live-wire performances (no ritual immolation but lots of smashing and dropping of plates and vases).

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: Nashville, Back for Season 5, Changes Channels
description: Juliette Barnes (Hayden Panettiere) wasnt the only one whose survival was in question when her plane fell off the radar in the Season 4 finale of Nashville in May. The series had been canceled by ABC, and the cliffhanger offered only the faintest hope of resuscitation for the show or its country superstar.

title: The Paint Formulator: More Than Mixing Colors
description: Ulysses Jackson, 35, is a paint formulator at Golden Artist Colors in New Berlin, N.Y.

title: Presidential Portraits: Staring History in the Face
description: WASHINGTON  An inescapable fact of American elections is that a new presidents mug may soon be in your face, nonstop. For Donald J. Trump, a corollary is that he, like all newcomers to office, can keep company with the mugs of his choosing, decorating the Oval Office with presidential portraits  typically the official ones in the collections on view at the White House and the National Portrait Gallery.

title: Review: In God of Vengeance, a Nice Jewish Family Lives Above a Brothel
description: Questions of guilt and retribution gnaw ceaselessly at the heart of Yankl (Shane Baker), the central character in Sholem Aschs God of Vengeance, which is being given a timely revival by the New Yiddish Rep at LaMaMa. A pious Orthodox Jew, Yankl makes his living in what remains a highly unorthodox profession: He owns a brothel that sits below the apartment in which his family lives.

title: Eat, Drink, Dance and Be Part of the Play
description: One Saturday night this month, as the audience queued up to enter The Grand Paradise, an immersive theater piece in Bushwick, Brooklyn, the Tony-winning actress Andrea Martin stood in line with the rest of us. On a video monitor overhead, cast members costumed like flight attendants explained what to expect.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: When Defendants Cannot Afford a Lawyer, and Neither Can New Mexico
description: HOBBS, N.M.  When Bennett J. Baur, New Mexicos chief public defender, took office in April, he set out to review the workload of every lawyer on his team, ahead of another year of belt-tightening in a state whose budget has been crippled by the slump in oil and gas prices.

title: China Builds Out the Air as Frustrations Mount Below
description: BEIJING  An angry mob ransacks a terminal. A frustrated passenger tries to leave the plane while it taxis. A pilot, who has had it up to here, advises fliers to leave the plane and mill about the tarmac  and they do.

title: Russia, Syria, Debbie Reynolds: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Where to Catch Music and Comedy on New Years Eve
description: AFROJACK Afrojack has been hovering near the top tier of global D.J.s for a few years now, but hes never quite connected as an artist on his own terms (like, say, the successful but uninspired Calvin Harris). But this year, he released Gone, an extremely temperate and sneakily effective collaboration with Ty Dolla Sign, and maybe theres more where that came from. At 8 p.m., the Gallery in the Dream Downtown, Manhattan; NYCNewYears.com. (Jon Caramanica)

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: For Kamasi Washington, Its About Keeping an Open Mind
description: Kamasi Washington began this year literally hobbled: After breaking an ankle on tour in Europe, he followed doctors orders and canceled a series of shows. Still, that pause hardly slowed the onrushing momentum that Mr. Washington, a commandingly charismatic tenor saxophonist and bandleader, has gathered since the release of his momentous debut, The Epic.

title: The Unsinkable Debbie Reynolds
description: Nobody like Debbie Reynolds is ever happening at the movies again. Wholl be as plucky? Wholl work as hard to stay as morally pure? Who the hell is gonna be named Debbie? These days, when we talk about showbiz, we have to adjust for deflation, because it just doesnt mean as much as it did when Ms. Reynolds was a star.

title: After Paladinos Racist Remarks, Buffalo School Board Demands He Resign
description: The Buffalo Board of Education on Thursday demanded that Carl Paladino resign from his post on the board after making racist comments about President and Michelle Obama last week. If he refuses to step down, the board will ask the state education commissioner to remove him, it said in a resolution.

title: Simon Starling: Modernism Gazing Into the Past
description: Modernism is our antiquity, the historian T. J. Clark wrote in Farewell to an Idea, his 1999 eulogy for the art of the last century. By which he meant: As Greece and Rome served as the base line for Western culture from the Renaissance onward, modernism itself had become our model and myth, to be reinterpreted at will but never really understood. Spend half a day in Chelsea, and you will see few gods and heroes  but you will trip over archives of failed utopian collectives, photos of crumbling tower blocks, rebooted avant-garde dances and all sorts of fragments of the recent past. Ulysses may be dead, but Ulysses endures.

title: What to See in New York City Galleries This Week
description: Through Jan. 21. Craig F. Starr Gallery, 5 East 73rd Street, Manhattan; 212-570-1739, starr-art.com.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: An Artist Emerges From His Brooklyn Sanctuary
description: For more than 30 years, Taro Ichihashi has been working away in near-seclusion behind a metal roll-down gate protecting 551 Grand Street in Brooklyn.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: Carrie Fishers Fans Find Solace in Her Books
description: I heard someone once say that were only as sick as our secrets, Carrie Fisher wrote in her 2008 memoir Wishful Drinking.

title: Is There a New York City Law Against Long Dog Leashes?
description: Q. I recently had to step over a dog leash that was stretched across the sidewalk while the owner chatted with an employee in a store entrance. What is the law regarding length of leashes? Also, do dogs have to be microchipped?

title: George S. Irving, Tony Winner and Voice of Heat Miser, Dies at 94
description: George S. Irving, a Tony Award-winning actor who was in the original Broadway casts of Oklahoma! and Gentlemen Prefer Blondes and amused a wide audience pitching White Owl cigars on television, died on Monday in Manhattan. He was 94.

title: U.S. Correctional Population at Lowest Level in Over a Decade
description: The nations jail and prison population decreased in 2015, according to federal data released on Thursday, and the number of adults locked up or on parole or probation fell to a level not seen since 2002 while overall crime continued to drop.

title: Cockroaches Are His Friends
description: Aaron Rodriques has his priorities in order.

title: To the Man With One Shoe
description: Dear Diary:

title: LaVell Edwards, Coach Who Led B.Y.U. to a Football Title, Dies at 86
description: LaVell Edwards, who took over a perennially lackluster Brigham Young University football program in 1972, orchestrated a string of winning seasons with innovative passing attacks run by All-American quarterbacks and coached the Cougars to the 1984 national championship, died on Thursday at his home in Provo, Utah. He was 86.

title: Peabody Energy and Native Americans in Dispute Over Mining in Arizona
description: KAYENTA, Ariz.  The worlds largest coal company, Peabody Energy, is seeking federal approval to expand its mine on Navajo and Hopi land in northern Arizona, a move supported by tribal leaders. But many other tribe members say the expansion would destroy burial grounds and pre-Columbian ruins and are opposing it in court.

title: Protecting the Rights of Our Protectors
description: The New York Police Department sent a message of religious tolerance on Wednesday when Commissioner James ONeill announced a policy change that will allow the citys officers who observe the Sikh faith to wear beards and turbans while in uniform, if the turban is blue and displays the departments shield.

title: The Russian Hacking in 200 Words
description: President Obama announced sanctions against Russia for trying to influence the 2016 election through cyberattacks. Heres what led to the sanctions.

title: Garbage Trucks Will Help Protect New York for New Years Eve
description: When revelers begin arriving at Times Square on Saturday to ring in the new year, they will hear the familiar sound of police helicopters overhead, go through the mandatory bag screenings and see the usual mass of police officers. But they will also be greeted by something that has only recently become a regular feature of the citys security infrastructure: strategically positioned garbage trucks loaded with sand.

title: In Red and Blue Israel, Separate Lives and Divergent Narratives
description: JERUSALEM  The two front-page headlines told very different stories about Secretary of State John Kerrys lengthy address about Middle East peace.

title: Second Avenue Subway Ringing in New Year With Party
description: It stands to be New York Citys New Years Eve party of the century, or, at least, it took a century to happen.

title: American Jews Divided Over Strain in U.S.-Israel Relations
description: For Rabbi Gerald Sussman of Temple Emanu-El on Staten Island, the Obama administrations recent confrontation with Israel was a stunning turn for a president who had enjoyed support from many members of his congregation. The word betrayed would not be too strong a word, he said.

title: Argentine Court Reopens Investigation of Ex-President in 94 Bomb Case
description: PARAN, Argentina  An Argentine court reopened an investigation on Thursday into accusations that former President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner sought a secret deal with Iran in connection with the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center in Buenos Aires. The original case was filed by Alberto Nisman, the prosecutor whose mysterious death in 2015 convulsed the country.

title: Next Stop: Rikers
description: On the New York City bus that runs to the Rikers Island jail complex, Salvador Espinoza captured images of inmates friends and relatives.

title: President Obama Punishes Russia, at Last
description: While it is definitely too late, and may also be too little, there should be no doubt about the correctness of President Obamas decision to retaliate against Russia for hacking American computers and trying to influence the 2016 presidential election.

title: A Communal Struggle on the Bus to Rikers
description: Going to jail might seem like an intensely personal experience, the sort of thing that one must pass through alone. But those close to the inmate are also affected: To paraphrase an old saying, when someone serves time, the family serves it with them.

title: UConn Extends Streak to 87, Shrugging Off No. 4 Maryland
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  The last time the Connecticut womens basketball team lost a game, the Huskies looked very different.

title: John Kerry and Israel: Too Little and Too Late
description: In a speech this week laying out the Obama administrations parameters for a final peace agreement between Israel and Palestine, Secretary of State John Kerry stated what has been obvious to most observers for many years: that Israels construction of Jewish settlements on occupied Palestinian land has all but destroyed the two-state solution. Unfortunately, Mr. Kerrys speech offers far too little, and comes much too late.

title: Exiting a Bad Road Onto a Hopeful Path
description: She watched as her friends were killed in gang wars. She knew others who took lives.

title: Two Russian Compounds, Caught Up in Historys Echoes
description: WASHINGTON  A pair of luxurious waterfront compounds outside New York and Washington have for decades been a retreat for Russian diplomats, places to frolic in the water, play tennis and take lengthy steam baths.

title: Inmate Seeks New Trial in 1993 Killing, Saying Ex-Detective Pressured Witness
description: Lawyers for a Brooklyn man imprisoned for more than 20 years in a fatal shooting asked a judge on Thursday to grant him a new trial, saying that the sole eyewitness against him now says she was pressured to identify him by a former detective who has been accused of falsifying evidence in several other cases.

title: Goodness Gracious
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  The end of the year makes me both sentimental and conscious of how quickly time passes. Life keeps us very busy, but I think its important to press the pause button once in a while to acknowledge and express gratitude.

title: The State of the War in Syria
description: Some of the major developments in Syria surrounding a cease-fire agreement reached Thursday.

title: Uncertainty Over New Chinese Law Rattles Foreign Nonprofits
description: BEIJING  The hotline rings, but nobody answers.

title: Spies vs. Spies: A Cold War Regularity That Never Quite Cooled
description: Since the end of the Cold War, a variety of leaked diplomatic cables, captured operatives and acts of espionage, like this summers hacking of the Democratic National Committee, have served as reminders that Russia and the United States continue to routinely spy on each other.

title: Rashaan Salaams Family Declines to Test His Brain for Trauma
description: The family of the 1994 Heisman Trophy winner Rashann Salaam, who killed himself earlier this month, declined to have his brain tested to determine whether his depression had been linked to head trauma from his days as a player.

title: Russia, Syria, Serena Williams: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Discovering Aucklands Charms (and Idioms)
description: We were chugging along up State Highway 1: Robyn Goulevitch was in the drivers seat, I was in the passenger seat (which is on the left in New Zealand, remember), and a sweet but very impatient dog named Tobi was in the back. On the North Island, which is shaped a bit like a birds head, we were moving slowly toward the tip of the beak.

title: Corrections: December 30, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Whats on TV Friday: Ben Affleck in The Accountant and Love Is Strange
description: While we wait for television shows to return from holiday hiatus, lets check out films that have been added to streaming platforms. The Accountant, a quiet thriller starring Ben Affleck, is on iTunes. And Amazon Prime offers Love Is Strange, Ira Sachss touching portrait of lifelong love.

title: In a Brutal Year in Venezuela, Even Crime Fighters Are Killers
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The soldiers barged into Rafael Gonzlezs home as his mother and girlfriend looked on. It would be a routine questioning, they assured him and others arrested that night, before hauling them off to a dark military barracks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: They told me: We are going to play a game, Little Rafael. It is called electrocution.

title: The 2016 Sidney Awards, Part Deux
description: Every December I read hundreds of long-form essays to select the Sidney Awards, and every year I regret that I spend so much of the other 11 months reading online trivia. Then, every January, I revert to Twitter.

title: Snatching Health Care Away From Millions
description: If James Comey, the F.B.I. director, hadnt tipped the scales in the campaigns final days with that grotesquely misleading letter, right now an incoming Clinton administration would be celebrating some very good news. Because health reform, President Obamas signature achievement, is stabilizing after a bumpy year.

title: New Yorks New Subway Is a Century Overdue
description: Glory, glory, hallelujah! New Years Day is about to bring New Yorkers what many of their ancestors never lived to see: the opening of the Second Avenue subway. Or, as the Metropolitan Transportation Authority put it in a news release, the historic, on-time opening of the Second Avenue subway.

title: Feminism Lost. Now What?
description: This was supposed to be the year of triumph for American women.

title: A Less Than Honorable Policy
description: Kristofer Goldsmith spent the end of his teenage years photographing mutilated bodies. Mr. Goldsmith knew that he would face bullets and bombs when he enlisted in the Army shortly after Sept. 11, and like almost every soldier of his generation, he volunteered to serve with the understanding that he would go to war. He made sergeant in just over two years and spent an entire year in Baghdad.

title: Australias Death by Numbers
description: The dead refugee had a name. But even in death Australia did not want to humanize him. For years now he had been no more than a registration number  BRF063  under the countrys cruel refugee deterrence system known as offshore processing.

title: How to Build an Igloo
description: Make friends with winter, says Norbert E. Yankielun, an engineer who has written about igloo construction. Igloos are the most specialized form of a snow shelter, and you need a special type of snow to do it right. The truly appropriate snow is somewhere where there is not a freeze-and-thaw cycle. That kind of weather destroys the structural integrity of the snow. But even though ideal igloo-making environments are closer to the polar regions, its not impossible to replicate good conditions elsewhere.

title: Dont Call Them Mocktails
description: Im always thrilled when a certain former drinking buddy comes to see me at the bar. He stopped drinking alcohol years ago, but hes as fun to be around as he was when we sat side by side at a corner bar in TriBeCa many nights in the 90s  probably more so.

title: In the New Year, More Cuddling
description: Attending a cuddle party was one of my fear-conquering New Years resolutions for 2016. My other resolutions  I had a long list  included speed dating and taking a hike with a mountaineering club.

title: Tips for Creating a Home for Aging Owners
description: A range of renovations and adjustments can be made to our apartments or houses to help us stay in our homes for as long as possible.

title: They Maintain a Hotels Patina of Opulence
description: Brayan De La Cruz swirled a cloth along the inside rim of a $260 cobalt blue champagne flute. He raised it to the fluorescent lights overhead, and squinted up at it.

title: The 12.18.16 Issue
description: RE: A.I.

title: Tracing the Blue Blood of New Yorks Elite
description: Ward McAllister became the arbiter of Gilded Age society in 1888 when he defined the Four Hundred  supposedly the number of true aristocrats in New York, which also happened to match the number of people Mrs. Astor could accommodate in her ballroom.

title: Why I Am Like New Zealand
description: The comparison expressed by the poems title at first seems lighthearted but quickly reveals physical and psychological pain: Death thrives, tectonic plates hurt. Is this a poem about aging? The end of a love affair? The environment? Maybe all three. The dark thinking of the poem continues until the surprising swerve in the last two lines, which leaves us in what W.H. Auden called the clear expression of mixed feelings. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

title: Looking for a Friend in Old Age
description: Last June, as there was no poplar fluff to bother me yet in Novaya Usman, I got in the habit of spending my days outside. Novaya Usman is a small village in southern Russia near the city of Voronezh, and I have lived here for more than a decade. I am now 80, and at my age it is hard to walk for very long, so I would sit on a lavochka, a wooden bench, near my house and watch the people go by. I also daydreamed about life back at Almaty, thousands of miles away. If nostalgia became unbearable, I headed back home.

title: Push the Ball! Box Out! Zone! Did You Get All That, Viewers?
description: Steve Scheer is a basketball junkie. He had often fantasized about eavesdropping on a coachs huddle during timeouts. The short, edited snippets on some telecasts were hardly enough to satisfy his appetite for access.

title: Loneliness Can Be Deadly for Elders; Friends Are the Antidote
description: The circle shrinks. As the years pass, older people attend too many funerals. Friendships that sustained them for decades lapse when companions and confidants retire or move away or grow ill.

title: At Years End, Catching Up With New Yorks Oldest Old
description: In 2015, The New York Times documented a year in the lives of six New Yorkers over age 85, one of the fastest-growing age groups in America. All six survived the year, an accomplishment in itself. This past year, I kept in touch with the group to see how they were doing.

title: Six Feet Across and Full of Peril: Englands Killer Creek
description: It sure doesnt look like a killer.

title: Fish Seek Cooler Waters, Leaving Some Fishermens Nets Empty
description: POINT JUDITH, R.I.  There was a time when whiting were plentiful in the waters of Rhode Island Sound, and Christopher Brown pulled the fish into his long stern trawler by the bucketful.

title: Home Renovation for the Golden Years
description: Home renovations often center on upgrading the kitchen cabinets or selecting a new paint color for the bedroom, but as long as you are at it, a well-thought-out redesign might also include modifications to help you stay in your home as you grow older.

title: Join Our Board: Companies Hotly Pursue New Wave of Women in Tech
description: SAN FRANCISCO  For months, technology companies have pursued Amy Chang.

title: Second Avenue Subways Arrival Brings Fear That Rents Will Soar
description: Few cities in the world are as closely linked to their subways as New York City  the vast network helped shape the city and now carries nearly six million people a day. So when the most ambitious expansion of the subway system in half a century opens on Sunday, it will be a transformative moment, promising to alter the future of a large slice of Manhattan.

title: Floating Over Oz With Glinda
description: Eight times a week, Glinda the Good Witch makes a grand entrance from above the stage in the Broadway production of Wicked. Ride along with her on the flight.

title: Russia, Syria, 2017: Your Friday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Peter Handkes Time-Traveling Tale of a Europe in Flux
description: THE MORAVIAN NIGHTA StoryBy Peter HandkeTranslated by Krishna Winston312 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.

title: Can Psychiatric Drugs Blunt the Mother-Baby Bond?
description: Question:

title: New York Today: A New Year Brings a New Subway Line
description: Good morning on this frosty Friday.

title: A Celebration of American Innovation, From the Erie Canal to Jazz to the MRI
description: AMERICA THE INGENIOUSHow a Nation of Dreamers, Immigrants, and Tinkerers Changed the WorldBy Kevin BakerIllustrated by Chris Dent262 pp. Artisan. $29.95.

title: An Amsterdam Hotel with Dutch Style and British Cheek
description: Starting at 129 euros, or $134.

title: A Restaurant in Michigans Vacation Region That Satisfies
description: Alliance, a small Traverse City bistro serving vegetable-forward shared plates, has been making waves in the northwest corner of Michigans Lower Peninsula since opening in March. But a heads up: Alliance is not Tapawingo II.

title: Coolest Scene in Snowboarding? The Coast of Rhode Island
description: A group of resourceful snowboarders in powder-poor Rhode Island, who call themselves the Yawgoons, are the envy of their peers around the world.

title: Vladimir Putin Wont Expel U.S. Diplomats as Russian Foreign Minister Urged
description: MOSCOW  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia announced Friday that he would not retaliate against President Obamas decision to expel Russian diplomats and impose new sanctions  only hours after his foreign minister recommended doing just that.

title: Your Photos as Princess Leia, a Rebel and Role Model
description: When Carrie Fisher was cast as Princess Leia in the 1977 film Star Wars, she was a 19-year-old with no idea that her character would come to mean so much for so many. Youre not just an actor in this movie, Ms. Fisher said, youre a diplomat to a country you didnt know existed.

title: 15 of Ts Most Enjoyable Stories in 2016
description: Great pieces that inspire, delight and make you think. (Just right for weekend reading.)

title: Theresa May Scolds Kerry for Focus on Israel Settlements
description: LONDON  Even the so-called special relationship is subject to limits, it seems.

title: Empathy Is Good, Right? A New Book Says Were Better Off Without It
description: AGAINST EMPATHYThe Case for Rational CompassionBy Paul Bloom285 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $26.99.

title: Gathering Storm: A History of the Complicated U.S.-China Relationship Since 1776
description: THE BEAUTIFUL COUNTRY AND THE MIDDLE KINGDOMAmerica and China, 1776 to the PresentBy John PomfretIllustrated. 693 pp. Henry Holt & Company. $40.

title: Comfort Woman Statue Reinstated Near Japan Consulate in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Bowing to public pressure, an official in South Koreas second-largest city said on Friday that activists could put up a statue representing Korean women forced into sexual slavery by Japan during World War II, a year after the two countries said they had put that emotional issue behind them.

title: Why I Talk About My Daughters Body
description: Were making our way out of the orthopedists office where my 11-year-old daughters broken foot has been wrapped in a hot pink cast, and Ive made what some deem the ultimate faux pas for a mom: Ive commented on her body.

title: Mahisha Dellinger of Curls on Becoming a Leader of Your Life
description: This interview with Mahisha Dellinger, chief executive of Curls, a maker of hair care products, has been edited for space and clarity.

title: The Ad That Moved People the Most: Bernie Sanderss America
description: They may be difficult to recall, but there were some things about the 2016 presidential election that made people happy and hopeful. Perhaps even harder to believe is that some of those things were campaign advertisements.

title: A Few Questions for Poetry
description: Why Poetry? Well, yes. Most books of poetry sell a couple of thousand copies, at best. So in a quantitative sense, whats the point of supporting it? With dollars or sense? Would we make the same argument for investing in an endangered species? Like the great Indian bustard, one of the heaviest flying birds, down to a couple of hundred of its kind.

title: How Syria Defeated the Sunni Powers
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, three of the Middle Easts major Sunni powers, once equated their standings in the region with the outcome of the war in Syria. Since the uprising broke out in 2011, they have been stalwart  if often divided  supporters of the rebels in their fight against the government of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Families in Fiction
description: THE HOUSE AT THE EDGE OF NIGHTBy Catherine Banner419 pp. Random House, $27.

title: California Today: The Stories That Moved Us in 2016
description: Good morning.

title: Ludovico Einaudi, a Classical Artist for the YouTube Age
description: The Italian composer and pianist Ludovico Einaudi, 61, is one of the worlds most-streamed classical artists, with more followers on Spotify (about 740,000) than Mozart (680,000). His music, by turns minimal and lush, incorporates an array of influences from Bach to rock to West African kora music. While sold-out audiences across Europe find something sublime in his searching style, some classical critics disagree  like Ben Beaumont-Thomas of The Guardian, who says its nothing more than the dashed-off poignancy of an Instagrammed sunset.

title: The Story Behind This Weeks Best Sellers
description: Star Power: This weeks lists reflect book sales for the period ending Dec. 24, which means youll find lots of famous novelists on the fiction side of the ledger: In publishing as in home electronics, brand names sell well for the holidays. They know it, too. Heres John Grisham  whose thriller The Whistler remains No. 1 in its ninth week on the hardcover fiction list  describing his target audience in a November interview with Slate: First of all, shes female, because two-thirds of all books are bought by women. Shes going to buy it during the Christmas season, because 35 percent of all books are sold during the Christmas season. I would guess shes probably going to be over 40, because they buy more books than under 40. And that kind of narrows it down. Thats probably my typical reader. In the same interview, Grisham said he often writes from a sense of injustice about a given subject  dont be surprised if he tackles student debt in a future thriller  and he gave vent, just a bit, to his political views. The short version: He doesnt think much of Donald Trump. The slightly longer, more diplomatic version: I still pull for the underdog. I still like the little guy, especially when the little guy is getting screwed by the big guy: the government, a corporation, an issue, whatever. ... But youve got to be careful with your audience, because they dont always share my politics. You cant be intrusive with your politics in popular fiction, when youre trying to entertain people. I really have to watch that, and I do watch it. I dont feel a responsibility to write a book next year that might change something. My responsibility next year is to write a book that will entertain.

title: A Voice of Christmas Past Returns, Asking for a Hippopotamus
description: This years holiday advertising campaign for the United States Postal Service featured a little girls stunningly infectious musical plea: I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmas. (And, as she explains, Only a hippopotamus will do.) The ditty was, perhaps, unfamiliar to many listeners, but it penetrated the mind space of the unwary at warp speed  and stayed there. Resistance was futile.

title: After a Year of Faulty Predictions, 3 Approaches to Investing
description: There is one thing analysts can agree on about the year that is coming to a close: 2016 confounded predictions and expectations. From how stocks would perform to who would win the presidency, this was a bad year for people who tell us what tomorrow will bring.

title: A New York City Driveway: Blessing or Curse?
description: Many New York City car owners would want nothing more than a designated parking space  such is the desperation many feel in this city so clogged with cars yet so starved for places to put them.

title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
description: Our foreign correspondents wrote about dozens of captivating people and places in 2016, from pirates in the Amazon to tourists in the nomad lands of Tibet to transgender goddesses in India. We hope their journals and dispatches  conversational and visual on-the-ground reports  gave you a welcome break from the news.

title: Toga Parties, Gangsters and Near-Death Experiences: 27 Years With The Times
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Walter R. Baranger, a senior editor for News Operations, reflects on memorable moments in a career that took him to Afghanistan, Tajikistan and beyond.

title: How to Nurse Your Hangover (and Head One Off)
description: Your head feels like its inside a bass drum, your mouth is cottony and the contents of your stomach might not stay put.

title: After Building a Media Empire, Whats Next? Lifting One Million From Poverty
description: NATE, India  Ronnie Screwvala sat cross-legged early last month on the floor of a three-room schoolhouse here in Nate, a village about 100 miles from Mumbai, the city of his birth where he built a billion-dollar media conglomerate. Watching a group of children playing with colorful educational games, Mr. Screwvala, a boyish-looking 54-year-old, appeared as wide-eyed and engaged as the students.

title: Wife and Her Lover Are Arrested in Killing of Greek Envoy in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The killing of the Greek ambassador was shocking even by the standards of this crime-weary city: Investigators say his wife had him murdered in a home they owned in Rio by her lover, a police officer, who then set the diplomats remains on fire.

title: Predictions for a Trump Presidency
description: Heres something we did not predict a year ago: that Russia would hack the Democratic National Committee to undermine faith in the 2016 election and that the winner of that race, President-elect Donald J. Trump, would shrug off the entire episode by telling the country to move on as he stood next to Don King, a boxing promoter and convicted felon.

title: Step Into a Refugee Camp
description: The Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan is one of the largest Syrian camps in the world. In the fall, we visited the camp live with our audience. Heres what we heard from the refugees and from you.

title: Syrian Refugees on the War, Their Camp, and Your Questions
description: In September, we visited a Syrian refugee camp while live on Facebook, and brought The New York Timess audience along. We went to the Zaatari refugee camp in Jordan, one of the largest Syrian camps in the world, after our audience said in countless comments that they wanted to see and interact with Syrian refugees.

title: Does It Pay to Buy a House in the Suburbs?
description: Q. My husband and I are in our 30s and used to rent in Brooklyn. After we had a baby, we moved to the suburbs. Were now thinking about buying a house, but I cant wrap my mind around how it would be financially advantageous. In Port Washington on Long Island, we pay $2,600 a month in rent for a beautiful apartment. For a barely livable house, we would pay at least $3,600 a month, not counting the additional expenses of ownership. From my estimates, we will save $12,000 a year if we continue to rent. What am I missing?

title: Raymond Pettibon: Pictures, Literary Voices and Surfers, Too
description: In his energetic drawings of baseball greats, Hollywood legends, comic book heroes and rock stars, of drug addicts, bikers and gangsters, Charles Manson and J. Edgar Hoover, Raymond Pettibon gives us the full sweep of the American social landscape.

title: Catholic Churches in China Should Be Independent of Vatican, Official Says
description: BEIJING  A top Chinese official suggested that Catholic churches in China should be run independently of the Roman Catholic Church, the state news media reported on Friday, striking a nationalistic tone as the country negotiates a possible deal to improve relations with the Vatican.

title: Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher: Hollywoods Mother-Daughter Fable
description: Some years ago I had the privilege of a long evening with Carrie Fisher, starting at her house in Beverly Hills and proceeding to a nearby restaurant, and she talked so expansively  about her memories of Star Wars, about her electric shock treatments, about Diet Coke, about everything  that I didnt come away with just a few impressions of her. I came away with a few hundred.

title: Cheetahs in Danger of Extinction, Researchers Say
description: The cheetah, as swift as it is in the hunt, will not be able to outrun the threats to its survival without new conservation efforts, according to an international team of researchers who reported their findings in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

title: If Donald Trump Targets Journalists, Thank Obama
description: WASHINGTON  If Donald J. Trump decides as president to throw a whistle-blower in jail for trying to talk to a reporter, or gets the F.B.I. to spy on a journalist, he will have one man to thank for bequeathing him such expansive power: Barack Obama.

title: Sleepy New Jersey Town Wakes to a New Identity: Trumps Camp David North
description: BEDMINSTER, N.J.  The local roads were closed, with Secret Service agents, the state police and local law enforcement on patrol. Deep in a protective bubble, President-elect Donald J. Trump was holding court in his living quarters not long after his election, receiving would-be members of his future administration at his country club. A crush from the news media waited outside for a photo opportunity. But there was little traffic, no protesters and few gawkers  except for a herd of horses, idly chewing grass.

title: A Documentary on Fisher and Reynolds to Air Sooner on HBO
description: HBO announced on Friday that it was moving up the debut of Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds, a documentary about the daughter and mother who died this week. The film was to air in the spring; it will now be shown on HBO next Saturday night, Jan. 7.

title: Mongolia, With Deep Ties to Dalai Lama, Turns From Him Toward China
description: Mongolia, whose rulers played a role in establishing the Dalai Lama centuries ago, no longer welcomes him.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Carrie Fisher, Debbie Reynolds and Year-End Hazards
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: What I Love | David Burke
description: The chef and restaurateur, who recently opened a new place on the Upper East Side, lives in a high-rise penthouse in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: David Burke, Celebrity Chef: Collector or Hoarder?
description: When you visit David Burkes bright, airy two-bedroom penthouse apartment in a high-rise rental building in Fort Lee, N.J., you can chow down on the pastrami salmon, the candied bacon and the burrata, all prepared by Mr. Burke, the celebrated chef whose newest restaurant, Tavern 62 by David Burke, opened in mid-October on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Cease-Fire in Syria Frays but Holds, Giving Hope to Peace Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Amid scattered reports of clashes and airstrikes, a cease-fire between the Syrian government and rebel groups tentatively took hold across the country on Friday, signaling a fragile peace that could lead to talks aimed at ending more than five years of fighting.

title: Rents and the Second Avenue Subway
description: First proposed nearly a century ago, the Second Avenue subway, or at least a portion of it between 63rd and 96th Streets, is finally scheduled to be up and running in the new year. An extension of the Q line will add new stations at 72nd, 86th and 96th Streets. One might expect that a decade of noisy construction would have kept rents down along this stretch of Second Avenue, but a recent study by StreetEasy indicates otherwise.

title: Trump and the Art Market: A Feel-Good Factor?
description: LONDON  As we enter 2017, and the inauguration of Donald J. Trump looms, many sectors of the global economy are wondering what impact his presidency will have on their business. The art market is one of them.

title: 1966: Chinas First Lady Admits She Plotted Against Maoism
description: HONG KONG  For Lady Bird Johnson to announce suddenly that she has been plotting to overthrow the U.S. government is unimaginable. Yet an admission of that magnitude has been made by the wife of the Peking regimes chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, in one of the most remarkable documents to emerge from the convulsions currently shaking Communist China.

title: A Universe of Bubbles in Every Champagne Bottle
description: A cork pops. The sudden change in pressure releases carbon dioxide trapped in the bottle. Bubbles form. They ride along as liquid falls from the bottle to your champagne glass. Once inside, a million of them cling against its edges before rising to the top and bursting  like supernovas  as soon as they hit the air. The explosion releases tiny droplets of liquid, and for a moment, your mouth contains a universe. The droplets dart across it like shooting stars that crash against your tongue. The aromatic landing of the fermented grapes is sharp, crisp, sweet, dry, delicate, delightful. This may be how you welcome 2017.

title: What Happened When Venezuela Outlawed Its Own Currency
description: In mid-December, the Venezuelan government surprised its citizens by withdrawing from circulation the 100-bolvar note, its largest and most used bill, with only 72 hours warning. Heres what happened next.

title: George Michaels Autopsy Is Inconclusive; Police Order More Tests
description: An autopsy of George Michael, the British pop star who died last week, was found to be inconclusive as to the cause of his death, police said on Friday.

title: 10 Songs That Tell the Story of 2016
description: So far on the Popcast, we have assessed 2016 using wide umbrellas  discussing the biggest trends and most influential news stories; measuring artists by the success of their full-length albums; and taking in all the movements, grand and small, that have been shaping jazz.

title: Run-DMC Sues Amazon and Walmart for Infringement
description: Run-DMC, the 80s hip-hop group, wants its brand back.

title: One Final Thought for 2016: Everybody Stinks
description: Are you one of the worlds greatest athletes? Did you win an Olympic gold medal, the Masters or the Kentucky Derby?

title: Free Market for Education? Economists Generally Dont Buy It
description: The odds are good that privatizing education will be part of the agenda for President-elect Donald J. Trumps administration. The Republican platform calls for increasing the role of banks in giving out student loans. And Mr. Trump and the platform advocate an expansion of both vouchers, which enable students to attend the private school of their choice with government funds, and charter schools.

title: Two Irish Girls Who Made It to New York
description: In January 2014, a girl from Cobh, Ireland (formerly known as Queenstown) journeyed across the Atlantic, skipped rosy-cheeked off an airplane at John F. Kennedy International Airport to start her new life. That was me, compensating for my indoor ghost face with too much blush in a shade aspirationally entitled orgasm. In January 1892, a girl from Queenstown (now known as Cobh) skipped rosy-cheeked off a boat at Ellis Island to start her new life. That was Annie Moore, flushed with embarrassment at the unexpected fuss being made of her by the officials on the island. She was the first immigrant through the new processing center that opened its doors on Jan. 1 of that year.

title: George Michaels Freedom Video: An Oral History
description: Pop music and fashion never met cuter than in George Michaels Freedom! 90 video. Sure, other catwalk favorites starred in music videos during that era, and fashion photographers like Steven Meisel and Herb Ritts were recruited by stars such as Madonna, Chris Isaak and Janet Jackson to burnish their visuals.

title: 10 Things to Do Now in NYC
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: N.F.L. Schedule: Who We Think Will Win in Week 17
description: In 2014, the Packers won one for the Limper. Last year, they won with the Miracle in Motown.

title: New York City Opera, on the Rebound With a Boost From Bernstein
description: A few weeks ago, a little more than three years after New York City Opera declared bankruptcy and was left for dead, its unlikely reincarnation was proceeding in a rehearsal studio near Herald Square.

title: Back Up Your iTunes Collection  or Your Whole Computer
description: Q. I know you can re-download albums and movies purchased from iTunes, but I have songs from other online stores, personal videos and home-ripped files in my collection as well. What is the easiest way to make a local backup of my entire set of iTunes libraries?

title: For This Choreographer, One Size Does Not Fit All
description: All artists spend time living in their imaginations, but over the past several years the choreographer Trajal Harrell seems to have signed a long-term lease.

title: Tracee Ellis Ross, Bill Hader, Zac Posen and Jurnee Smollett-Bell on Their TV of the Year
description: We asked some of this years notable authors, actors and showrunners about the TV they enjoyed most in 2016. Come back to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site, to read them all.

title: Church Militant Theology Is Put to New, and Politicized, Use
description: A week after Stephen K. Bannon helped engineer the populist revolt that led to Donald J. Trumps election, Buzzfeed unearthed a recording of him speaking to a Vatican conference of conservative Catholics in 2014.

title: Want Hopeful Signs From 2016? Look to Some of Its Aggravations
description: Looking for a way to end 2016 on a hopeful note? So was I when I went back through the columns I had written this year about the consumer issues that confused or annoyed me most.

title: China Says It Will Prosecute Ex-Security Official in Bribery Case
description: BEIJING  A former top Chinese security official who reportedly amassed an illicit fortune has been expelled from the Communist Party and will be prosecuted, the authorities announced on Friday.

title: Pan Pan, Father to a Generation of Pandas, Dies in China
description: Pan Pan, a giant panda whose virility helped spawn an entire generation of the notoriously difficult-to-breed animals, died this week at a conservation center in Chinas Sichuan Province.

title: Daily Report: Russia Is Punished for Hacking, but for How Long?
description: Hacking has dominated technology news over the course of 2016, with revelations of major breaches at Yahoo and the hacked emails of Democrats.

title: Holiday Style, on and Off the Ice, at the Rockefeller Center Rink
description: The first snow of the season had fallen, but that couldn't keep a mix of New Yorkers and visitors away from one of the citys most iconic holiday attractions: the ice rink at Rockefeller Center, which recently had its 80th anniversary. Visitors mostly dressed to ward off the cold, but this being New York, a few stylistic flourishes added some brio to the proceedings. We spoke to a few skaters and spectators about what they were wearing on a recent Saturday afternoon, a week before Christmas. This is what they told us.

title: What Nutmeg Can Tell Us About Nafta
description: GOA, India  For many years the word globalization was used as shorthand for a promised utopia of free trade powered by the worlds great centers of technological and financial innovation. But the celebratory note has worn thin. The word is now increasingly invoked to explain a widespread recoiling from a cosmopolitan earth. People in many countries are looking nostalgically backward, toward less connected, supposedly more secure times.

title: A Hit Christmas Song, and Its Star, Make a Comeback
description: Gayla Peevey sings "I Want a Hippopotamus for Christmas," the song that brought her a measure of fame in the '50s. The United States Postal Service featured the tune in its holiday ad campaign this year.

title: New Yorks Teamsters May Have Their Pensions Cut. What Went Wrong?
description: As troubled pension funds go, the New York State Teamsters Conference Pension and Retirement Fund, with some $1.3 billion in assets, is by no means the largest. Neither is it in the direst financial shape, even though just 44.8 percent of its obligations are funded.

title: Want to Play Football at Ohio State or Clemson? Try Playing Other Sports, Too
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  The Ohio State coaches had a 235-pound mass of potential to mold into a football player, but they could not agree on the form. As a freshman, Sam Hubbard was projected as a linebacker, but one member of the Buckeyes staff had designs on making him a tight end to plug a hole in the depth chart.

title: Exxon Favors a Carbon Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Gets an Opening from Russia, but the Path Is Risky
description: WASHINGTON  President-elect Donald J. Trump, who has pledged to reset relations with Russia, may have been tossed a lifeline by President Vladimir V. Putin on Friday. The Russian leader, skilled at keeping several steps ahead of his adversaries, announced that he would not retaliate against the Obama administration for imposing new sanctions and expelling Russian diplomats from the United States.

title: A Legacy of Slavery
description: To the Editor:

title: Blame Obama for Democrats Losses?
description: To the Editor:

title: Farro With Roasted Squash, Feta and Mint
description: Pair squash with farro for a delicious meatless main course.

title: Grain Bowl? Salad? Farro and Squash Can Go Either Way
description: How do you tell a grain bowl from a grain salad? The easiest way is to look at the serving vessel.

title: That Is So Fetch: A Mean Girls Musical Aims for Fall Run
description: It wont be easy to find a rhyme for Mathletes  as in, You cant join Mathletes, its social suicide!

title: Addressing the Trump Conflict Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: The Playlist: 21 Songs From 2016 That Nearly Got Away
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter (coming soon!) here.

title: Why Arent There More Female Billionaires?
description: Women have been rapidly climbing the employment and wage ladders in recent decades. But only a small fraction have made it to the top rungs  and their progress may be slowing.

title: Netflix Could Be Practical Magic for Disney
description: Walt Disney may be looking for a bit of two-for-one magic. The $160 billion entertainment conglomerate is on the hunt for technology to connect consumers directly with its movies and television shows. It is also in need of a successor to its chief executive, Bob Iger. A Netflix acquisition including its founder, Reed Hastings, might just answer both dreams  though it would be pricey.

title: Looking for Holiday Cheer? Look Elsewhere
description: Being a largehearted fellow with a deep and abiding faith in humanity, the Haggler likes to take the days between Christmas and New Years Day and look back at the warmth and good cheer he encountered in this column over the past 12 months.

title: Forcing a District Attorneys Hand
description: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Shaila Dewan, a national reporter covering criminal justice issues for The Times, recalls some of the strange things shes witnessed while reporting on low-level offenses, fines and fees in rural areas.

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are on the Upper East Side, in the Gramercy area and in Dumbo, Brooklyn.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: Shopping for Calendars
Walter E. Mattson, Former President of New York Times, Dies at 84
description: Walter E. Mattson, a former president and chief operating officer of The New York Times, who helped transform the newspaper with innovative labor agreements and new technologies, died on Friday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84.

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks properties are five-bedroom homes in Cherry Hill, N.J., and Centre Island, N.Y.
