title: Obama, Trump and Russian Hacking
description: To the Editor:

title: A Golden Age for American Whiskey Writers
description: If you havent been to a liquor store in a while, you may be surprised to find the shelves of whiskey groaning with American bottles. Now the same transformation is playing out at the bookstore.

title: Introducing the Stallone Sisters
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  It was a high-wattage room even by this citys standards. Emma Stone and Jessica Chastain were there, dressed to the nines. So were Judd Apatow and Jeff Bridges. As hunky waiters passed out hamachi tacos and mini bottles of Champagne, Kate Beckinsale, Chris Pine, Naomie Harris and Casey Affleck breezed by.

title: Germany Plans to Ring in the New Year With Heightened Security
description: BERLIN  Germans traditionally ring in the new year with a din of pyrotechnics and revelry, but the buzzword for this weekends celebrations is security.

title: An Alaskan Volcano Erupts, Largely Out of View
description: For a mere flyspeck, Bogoslof Island has been causing quite a commotion recently.

title: The Photos You Liked in 2016
description: Sometimes its easy to predict when a photo will catch the eyes of our Instagram followers. We had a feeling youd share our delight for the raccoons poised like bandits in Central Park. Fireworks and supermoons, too, are easy to like.

title: What Were Reading: The Direct Approach
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: 2 Condo Sales on Billionaires Row Lift the Market
description: A flurry of pricey condominium sales, many of them at Manhattans newest ultraluxury developments, provided a strong finale to an already robust 2016.

title: A Bad Year for New Yorkers. However ...
description: Yes, 2016 was a terrible year  for politics, civility, discourse, death. New Yorkers were forced to create bandwidth in their brains to accommodate the reality that one of the citys most storied and ridiculed tabloid personalities would lead the free world. David Bowie left his adopted city, and us. Homelessness rose. The Big Apple Circus, a beloved New York institution that brought the performing arts to poor children at no cost, had to shut down when it could not generate sufficient philanthropic interest. Skyrocketing costs forced the restaurant Da Silvano to close after 41 years in Greenwich Village. We  could go on at biblical length before we got to the downsizing of Gracious Home, the Manhattan purveyor of upscale home goods. But lets not. Let us instead, for the moment, consider the reasons we, as New Yorkers, may feel less terrible about the year that was and whats ahead:

title: Fears of Food Desert in High-End SoHo as Grocery Closes
description: SoHo offers a bounty of food  each block in this Manhattan neighborhood seems to feature artisanal chocolatiers selling single origin cacao, juice shops extruding vegetables for $9 a bottle and stores peddling cupcakes and Cronuts. Yet while high-end delicacies with gold bullion prices abound, humbler places to buy a jar of nonartisanal peanut butter or a sack of plain old gluten-full flour are much harder to find.

title: Among Deaths in 2016, a Heavy Toll in Pop Music
description: Death may be the great equalizer, but it isnt necessarily evenhanded. Of all the fields of endeavor that suffered mortal losses in 2016  consider Muhammad Ali and Arnold Palmer in sports and the back-to-back daughter-mother Hollywood deaths of Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds  the pop music world had, hands down, the bleakest year.

title: Your New Years Resolution? Make These Muffins
description: Luscious and thick glugs of custardy eggnog, spiked with three types of liquor, made spirits bright. Slices of rosy red rib roast, served with drippings-laden Yorkshire pudding, gave holiday plates heart-stopping heft. And crispy latkes, fried in pools of oil, were heaped with dollop after dollop of sour cream.

title: How Much Sugar Can You Avoid Today?
description: See if you can stay under a healthy limit.

title: A Month Without Sugar
description: It is in chicken stock, sliced cheese, bacon and smoked salmon, in mustard and salad dressing, in crackers and nearly every single brand of sandwich bread. It is all around us  in obvious ways and hidden ones  and it is utterly delicious.

title: Is The Mikado Too Politically Incorrect to Be Fixed? Maybe Not.
description: To devotees of British comic opera, The Mikado is one of the pinnacles of the genre. But, increasingly, it also represents an embarrassment.

title: Review: Wynton Marsaliss Urban Symphony for the Philharmonic
description: The next time Wynton Marsalis writes a symphony for the New York Philharmonic, he might want to plan from the start to keep it well under an hour. At least if he wants to assure that the Philharmonic will be able to perform it complete.

title: South Koreas Plan to Rank Towns by Fertility Rate Backfires
description: SEOUL, South Korea  For years, local officials in South Korea, which has one of the worlds lowest birthrates, have tried ever more inventive plans to encourage women to have babies.

title: Review: The Mick, From the Minds of Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia
description: Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia has made a nice little business out of being one of the nastiest little comedies on television. It begins its 12th season on Wednesday (originally on FX, its now on FXX) and has already been renewed for two more. To celebrate, its giving birth: The Mick, a new show from the Sunny brain trust (but not a spinoff), starts Sunday on Fox.

title: Cuomo Commutes Sentence of Judith Clark, Driver in Deadly Brinks Robbery
description: Judith Clark, who drove a getaway car in the infamous 1981 robbery of a Brinks armored car in Rockland County, N.Y., that left a guard and two police officers dead, went into prison defiant, with seemingly little chance of getting out. The judge who sentenced her saw her as beyond rehabilitation, giving her a minimum of 75 years in prison and all but ensuring she would die there.

title: Deutsche Bank Flew and Fell. Some Paid a High Price.
description: In 2005, Deutsche Bank, then a powerhouse in the selling of risky derivatives on a global scale, was minting money.

title: Review: Ransom, on CBS, Hopes Cooler Heads Prevail
description: In the fall of 2014, CBS served up a terrible drama called Stalker that followed a Los Angeles police unit assigned to cases involving stalking. It was exploitative and ugly and lasted only one season. On Sunday, the network proves that television never learns from past mistakes when it introduces Ransom, a series that, at least from the premiere, appears to have the same problems.

title: Syria, Russia, Mosul: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Friday Night Music: Lone Bellow
description: Taken on my phone last night. Truly awesome performance, as usual; gotta keep enjoying these moments, even as Trumpocalypse looms. Lots of standing ovations  partly, however, because, um, everyone is standing, since Bowery Ballroom doesnt have chairs.

title: In the Moment: Photographs From 2016
description: There is no easy way to sum up the rich smorgasbord that was culture in 2016. But  to stay with a culinary metaphor  this sampling of our arts photography offers a taste. These images take us behind the scenes to watch the Nigerian artist Laolu Senbanjo use the actress Danielle Brooks as his canvas. They make us privy to private moments, like those of a photo-averse Howard Stern in his studio; of Metropolitan Opera musicians taking a backstage poker break; of Taylor Mac applying makeup in front of his dressing room mirror. And they bring us closer to celebrities like Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Judith Light and Tony Bennett.

title: 2016 Was Our Archduke Franz Ferdinand
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

title: North Carolina Judge Delays Law Overhauling Elections Panel
description: In a second courtroom setback in two days for Republican leaders in North Carolina, a judge on Friday temporarily blocked a state elections board overhaul that had been condemned as a partisan diminishing of executive power.

title: Michael Skakels Murder Conviction Has Been Reinstated
description: In the latest twist in a case that has been full of them, the Connecticut Supreme Court ruled on Friday that the murder conviction of Michael C. Skakel, who was found guilty in 2002 of bludgeoning a teenage neighbor with a golf club, should be reinstated.

title: China Bans Its Ivory Trade, Moving Against Elephant Poaching
description: China announced on Friday that it was banning all commerce in ivory by the end of 2017, a move that would shut down the worlds largest ivory market and could deal a critical blow to the practice of elephant poaching in Africa.

title: Timeline of the Michael Skakel-Martha Moxley Case
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court has reinstated the conviction of Michael Skakel in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley. Here is a look at how the case has unfolded through the years.

title: Shielding Seized Assets From Corruptions Clutches
description: One would think that an iconic Michael Jackson Bad Tour glove, covered in Swarovski crystals and worn on his first solo tour, would rest in a place of honor, perhaps at the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland.

title: Cyril D. Tyson Dies at 89; Fought Poverty in a Turbulent Era
description: Cyril D. Tyson, who led antipoverty programs from inside and outside government in New York City and Newark in the 1960s in a tense racial atmosphere punctuated by violence, died on Thursday at his home in North Salem, N.Y. He was 89.

title: Cub Scouts Kick Out Transgender Boy in New Jersey
description: In 2013, the Boy Scouts of America ended its ban on openly gay youths participating in its activities.

title: Turning Over a New Leaf in 2017
Awaiting Trial in a Gilded Cage, a Rich Defendant Is Denied a Walk in the Park
description: When the Chinese billionaire Ng Lap Seng was arrested in New York on bribery charges in 2015, a judge allowed him to await trial not in a jail cell but in a spacious apartment in Midtown Manhattan, with GPS monitoring and 24-hour armed security guards  all at Mr. Ngs expense.

title: Venezuelas Deadliest Year
description: Amid an economic collapse, a wave of violence is afflicting the country.

title: To Make the World Better, Think Small
description: There is a legend about the comedian W. C. Fields as he lay dying in his hospital bed, surrounded by family. It was winter in New York City, and from outside came the sound of a newsboy shouting, Wuxtry! Wuxtry! Stock market prices fall! Stirred out of his stupor, Fields signaled those assembled to his bedside and whispered, Poor little urchins out there  undernourished, no doubt improperly clad  somethings got to be done about them, somethings got to be done. He dozed off, but seconds later, opened his eyes again. On second thought, he said, Screw em.

title: Costly Drug for Fatal Muscular Disease Wins F.D.A. Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved the first drug to treat patients with spinal muscular atrophy, a savage disease that, in its most severe form, kills infants before they turn 2.

title: The Lethal Allure of Stretch Limos
description: Eight young women out on a tour of Long Island wineries had both safety and comfort in mind when they booked a stretch limousine for their pre-wedding celebration in the summer of 2015. But four of them died and two were severely injured when the driver attempted a U-turn on a busy county highway and the long limousine was broadsided in traffic.

title: Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher, a Mother-Daughter Act for the Ages
description: For anyone who loves the spotlight, mothering can be an ideal role  for a while. The mother is a singular star to her baby, whose gaze follows her around the room with the watchfulness of an obsessive fan. For the stars Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds, that dynamic seemed to linger well into Ms. Fishers childhood: Ms. Fisher was the reverent observer, her mother the adored and observed.

title: Russias Contorted Denials on Doping
description: For a moment there it looked as if Russia had finally fessed up about its gigantic sports doping operation, even though a senior officials acknowledgment of an institutional conspiracy in an interview with Rebecca Ruiz of The Times was coupled with the usual whining about how Russia was being pilloried for what everybody does. But then the official, as well as the minister of sports, came back and said the comment was taken out of context. And just like that, the matter was back to square one.

title: A Quirk of Canadian History: When War and Hockey Shared the Ice
description: In Canada, the kinship between hockey and war is implicit. Both (of course) stoke patriotic pride, and theres the recognition (maybe) that the vivid game that remains closest to the national heart reflects the confusion and desperate violence of the battlefield, while also (somehow) naturally honoring warrior values of bravery and perseverance.

title: Cosby Lawyers Ask Judge to Change Trial Location
description: Lawyers for Bill Cosby asked a Pennsylvania judge on Friday to change the location or jury pool for his coming criminal trial on sexual assault charges, arguing that intense publicity surrounding the case has tainted any prospective jury in the county where the trial is scheduled to start in June.

title: Arthur H. Cash, Writer of British Biographies, Dies at 94
description: Arthur H. Cash, who wrote a definitive two-volume biography of the English novelist Laurence Sterne and became a Pulitzer Prize finalist in 2007 for his biography of the 18th-century English radical John Wilkes, died on Thursday in Watch Hill, R.I. He was 94.

title: Collision of 12-Game Winning Streaks Proves Rare for N.H.L., or Any League
description: ST. PAUL  Since its founding in 1917, the N.H.L. has never had a game like Saturdays matchup between the Columbus Blue Jackets and the Minnesota Wild at Xcel Energy Center: a regular-season matchup of two teams with winning streaks of at least 12 games.

title: The Game Will Go On as U.S. Expels Russian Diplomats
description: WASHINGTON  The spies are not particularly difficult to find. What is difficult is deciding what to do with them.

title: How Russians Pay to Play in Other Countries
description: PRAGUE  For a brief moment, it seemed that the powerful advisers head might roll at the Castle. After he lost his long legal battle over a hefty state fine, the Czech president warned him to pay up or lose his post.

title: Robert L. Hulseman, Inventor of the Solo Cup, Dies at 84
description: Robert L. Hulseman, a corporate executive who developed the sturdy red Solo cup that became indispensable at picnics, tailgate parties and barbecues and inspired a song by the country singer Toby Keith, died on Dec. 21 at his home in Northfield, Ill. He was 84.

title: Take a Bad Year. And Make It Better.
description: Lets pretend were in some cosmic therapists office, in a counseling session with the year 2016. We are asked to face the year and say something nice about it. Just one or two things.

title: Diplomatic Vehicles Vacate Russias Long Island Estate
description: UPPER BROOKVILLE, N.Y.  Seven miles from here, an old-world mansion known as the Killenworth estate became, briefly, a center of international intrigue on Thursday as reporters began descending on the property, long a weekend retreat for Russian diplomats. President Obama had just announced that he would be closing a Russian compound in New York that had been used for intelligence gathering  and several administration officials pointed to Killenworth, which is in Glen Cove, as the target in New York.

title: Not Around the Bend
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  Hello all! I feel so honored to be the Wordplay columns baby new year for 2017! How sad it is that in mere hours we must bid this fabulous year, as Im sure we all must agree weve had, adieu. Although behind the scenes here IRL I confess to having gotten a bit grizzled.

title: Canada Today: Reporting That Stood Out in 2016
description: For the final Canada Today newsletter of 2016, a selection of articles by New York Times correspondents who regularly report from the country.

title: Eternal Optimist Talking Points for 2017
The Ultimate Mother-Daughter Act
description: Susan Dominus looks back at the complicated and close relationship between Debbie Reynolds and Carrie Fisher, two Hollywood icons whose deaths were a day apart.

title: Corrections: December 31, 2016
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Tyrus Wong, Bambi Artist Thwarted by Racial Bias, Dies at 106
description: When Walt Disneys Bambi opened in 1942, critics praised its spare, haunting visual style, vastly different from anything Disney had done before.

title: The Lauded Russian Hacker Whose Company Landed on the U.S. Blacklist
description: MOSCOW  The blacklist includes two people suspected of cybercrimes, and four others who are military intelligence officers. All are the kinds of figures one might expect to be on a list of people targeted by the Obama administration in retaliation for Russias malfeasance, including efforts to influence the 2016 election.

title: Premier League Battle of Wits Starts Long Before Foot Meets Ball
description: MIDDLESBROUGH, England  Aitor Karanka, the Middlesbrough manager, spins in his chair and reaches behind him, sifting through the reports and the notes on the desk in his office at the teams training ground.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Moscow wanted Trump to have room to maneuver. This decision is a clear gesture of good will toward him.

title: 8 P.M.? Time for Children to Ring in the New Year With Fake Countdowns
description: Netflix has a trick for parents who want their children to ring in 2017 without staying up until midnight.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: New Years Eve
description: Its time to say goodbye to 2016. Somehow, we made it through a divisive election season and an agonizing number of celebrity deaths (not to mention catastrophes around the world). The general sentiment seems to be: Good riddance to this year. Here is how television networks are ringing in the new year  a better one, lets hope.

title: Rodeo Offers a 90-M.P.H. Glimpse of Texans Truck Mania
description: DRIPPING SPRINGS, Tex.  Tim Spell has noticed a peculiar condition that affects Texans mental, physical and automotive well-being.

title: Rift Between Officers and Residents as Killings Persist in South Bronx
description: After the bullet shells get counted, the blood dries and the votive candles burn out, people peer down from housing-project windows and see crime scenes gone cold: a band of yellow police tape blowing in the breeze.

title: Korean Official Charged With Illegally Swaying Samsung Merger Vote
description: SEOUL, South Korea  A former cabinet minister was arrested Saturday on charges that he illegally pressured the national pension fund to approve a merger between two Samsung subsidiaries, a deal that helped ensure that control of South Koreas most powerful conglomerate passed from its chairman to his son.

title: How Hemant Mathur, Indian Restaurateur, Spends His Sundays
description: After working 14-hour shifts six days a week as the executive chef and owner of Fine Indian Dining, a hospitality group that operates six Indian restaurants in Manhattan, including the recently opened Sahib in Curry Hill (around Lexington Avenue and 28th Street), Hemant Mathur tries to take Sundays off, but it rarely works. I inevitably end up working at least half the day, he said. Mr. Mathur, 49, does manage to spend time with his wife, Surbhi Sahni, 41, a pastry chef who also runs Bittersweet NYC, and their daughter, Soumyaa, 13. They live in Jackson Heights, Queens, where Mr. Mathur has lived since he immigrated from India nearly two decades ago.

title: At Cooks Arts & Crafts Shoppe, a Cozy Social Scene
description: The clean, modern lines of contemporary New York are absent here. Shelves and floor space are shrouded in heaps of soft yarn and fuzzy pompoms.

title: Scientists Loved and Loathed by an Agrochemical Giant
description: EXETER, England  The bee findings were not what Syngenta expected to hear.

title: Lighting Up the Sky Across the Globe
description: Delight in fiery festivals of 2016 from around the world  in Vilafranca del Peneds in Spain, Lewes in England and Brooklyn, New York.

title: A Peephole Camera in the South Bronx
description: A video camera installed in a peephole picked up hours of drug activity in the hallway of a South Bronx apartment building.

title: The Dog of the Day Site? Im Obsessed, and Heres Why
description: Bogie is athletic. She likes to walk, about four miles a day. She loves tetherball too, though she broke her leg in a recent game. Bogie can be shy and doesnt always do well in group situations. She enjoys chewing on the head of one of her friends, who is a cat.

title: A Night of (Mostly) Not Drinking With a Drynuary Expert
description: Other than some exceptions here and there, John Ore has not had an alcoholic drink during the month of January in 10 years. This is part of an annual seltzer-soaked exercise in temperance that he calls Drynuary.

title: The Most Read Styles Stories of 2016
description: Our readers couldnt resist these 10 articles.

title: Discounts at Caribbean Resorts, Even in High Season
description: Its high season in most tropical destinations, but a few deals can be found, especially at all-inclusive resorts.

title: My Father, the Shapeshifter
description: LOS ANGELES  On a warm September evening in the Hollywood Hills, guests at a book party for the writer Susan Faludi sipped prosecco and munched on lotus root chips in the courtyard of the Spanish-style home of the journalist Steve Oney and his wife, the interior designer Madeline Stuart. Book people mixed with movie people: Under a dense black acacia tree, the writer Amy Wilentz chatted with the television producer Nicole Yorkin; the historian Ed Larson rubbed elbows with the film producer Sean Daniel at the bar.

title: A Little Variety
description: VARIETY PUZZLES  This weeks puzzles include:

title: Damaged by War, Syrias Cultural Sites Rise Anew in France
description: PARIS  When the Islamic State was about to be driven out of the ancient city of Palmyra in March, Yves Ubelmann got a call from Syrias director of antiquities to come over in a hurry.

title: Calling on Angels While Enduring the Trials of Job
description: Angels are everywhere in the Muiz familys apartment in the Bronx: paintings of angels on the wall, ceramic angels flanking the ancient VCR, angels strumming lyres or blowing little golden trumpets on the bathroom shelves.

title: Trumps Indonesia Projects, Still Moving Ahead, Create Potential Conflicts
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  One resort, planned as the largest in Bali, will overlook a spectacular Hindu temple. The other, in the verdant hills of West Java, will adjoin a theme park. The properties will be so luxurious, the Trump Organization says, that even an impressive five-star rating will not do them justice. So it will give them six stars instead.

title: A Maverick Former Japanese Prime Minister Goes Antinuclear
description: TOKYO  William Zeller, a petty officer second class in the United States Navy, was one of hundreds of sailors who rushed to provide assistance to Japan after a giant earthquake and tsunami set off a triple meltdown at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant in 2011. Not long after returning home, he began to feel sick.

title: Giants Romeo Okwara Casts a Thoughtful Eye on the World
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Giants defensive end Romeo Okwara rarely leaves home without his camera. One of them, at least.

title: Propaganda With a Millennial Twist Pops Up in China
description: BEIJING  The two-minute cartoon opens with a folksy jingle and a smiling bobblehead of President Xi Jinping, dimpled and cherubic. Then it cuts to a colorful montage praising his government for improving the lives of ordinary Chinese with what might seem like a mundane policy: regulations allowing taxis to be summoned online.

title: Closing Chinas Ivory Market: Will It Save Elephants?
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  In the past 10 years, tens of thousands of elephants have been slaughtered across Africa to feed Chinas insatiable appetite for ivory. Entire herds from Gabon to Tanzania have disappeared. Even baby elephants have been killed for their tiny stubs of ivory. Scientists have said that the very survival of the species is in Chinas hands.

title: Kitty Dukakis, a Beneficiary of Electroshock Therapy, Emerges as Its Evangelist
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.  When Michael Dukakis lost the presidential election in 1988, his wife, Kitty, felt as if she had been squashed in a compactor, all the air forced out of her. Her even-keeled husband went back to work as governor of Massachusetts; she started binge drinking.

title: Jane Dickey and Jim Matson: A Snubbed Matchmaker Is Proven Right
description: Martha Jane Dickey and Albert James Matson were married Dec. 28 in St. Stephens Episcopal Church in Edina, Minn. The Rev. Thomas R. Cook, an Episcopal priest and the rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Is Donald Trump the Friend Israel Needs?
description: JERUSALEM  We cannot continue to let Israel be treated with such total disdain and disrespect. Thus President-elect Donald J. Trump tweeted just before Secretary of State John Kerry discussed the Israeli-Palestinian conflict last week. He added: They used to have a great friend in the U.S., but

title: Abby Jackson and Dominick Martn: Doing Splits, Literally and Figuratively
description: Abby Jackson and Dominick Benjamin Martn were married Dec. 31 at the Stone House at Stirling Ridge in Warren, N.J. The Rev. John Michael O'Sullivan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
description: Its so nice to start a new year with a cryptic; theyre very artisanal, I think, finely crafted little jewel boxes of puns and clever verbal sleights of hand. Its impossible to solve one while on end-of-year autopilot (or with a hangover!) and youre bound to feel a frisson of satisfaction when figuring out a particularly clever entry, and a little admiration for its constructor, all positive vibes for 2017.

title: Obamas Last Days: Aiding Trump Transition, but Erecting Policy Roadblocks
description: WASHINGTON  Only two days after the election, President Obama sat by President-elect Donald J. Trumps side in the Oval Office and declared that the No. 1 priority in his last days in the White House would be ensuring a smooth transition of power.

title: With Trump, Russia Goes From Thursdays Foe of U.S. to Fridays Friend
description: MOSCOW  The diatribe against the Obama administration on prime-time television by a Russian Foreign Ministry official was hardly unusual in the long history of rocky relations between the United States and Russia.

title: Patriotic Rapping
description: A rap group called CD REV says it wants to become a model for China's young people by promoting love  and patriotism.

title: In Trumps New Year Note, Love and a Jab at Enemies
description: Americans woke up on the last day of 2016 to a message from President-elect Donald J. Trump wishing them a happy new year.

title: Job No. 1 for a New Congress? Undoing Obamas Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Congress often waits for a new president to take office before it gets down to business. This year, Republicans will drop that custom in their dash to scrap the Affordable Care Act.

title: Los Angeles Has the Rams in Its Backyard, but the Raiders in Its Heart
description: LOS ANGELES  With the N.F.L. regular season about to end, the verdict among football fans in Los Angeles looks clear: Raiders 1, Rams 0.

title: House Republicans Fret About Winning Their Health Care Suit
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans have a new fear when it comes to their two-year-old health care lawsuit against the Obama administration: They might win.

title: Try a New Years Revolution
description: Donald J. Trump wants you on a diet.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Confessions of a Columnist
description: EVERY January I write a column exploring my faulty analysis and failed prophecies from the preceding year. After last years installment, in which I explained how I had underestimated a certain celebrity tycoon, I received a note from Trump Tower  a clipping of the column, scrawled over with a markered note:

title: Can Russia Make Peace as Well as War?
description: It was hard to greet the announcement last week of a new cease-fire in Syria without wariness. In six years of fighting, more than 400,000 people have been killed and entire cities devastated. This is a conflict that wouldnt have happened, or lasted so long, save for the cynical brutality of President Bashar al-Assad and his chief allies, Russia and Iran.

title: What Does It Mean to Acknowledge the Past?
description: The first time I heard it I was jet-lagged. Id flown 20 hours to Byron Bay in Australia from New York, and was sitting on a stage with other American authors under a tent in the rain. We were in that pocket of the world for a writers festival, and before our panel discussion began, a volunteer welcomed the soggy audience of more than 200 people and mentioned that the land was originally part of an indigenous nation. This, an outright mention of a displaced population, connecting the space to a time before colonialism, was something Id never experienced before. In Australia, its called an acknowledgment of country.

title: Chris Christies Book of Hubris
description: After a disastrous showing in the Republican presidential primaries and getting booted from the Trump transition team, Gov. Chris Christie returned home last month to the comfort of his power base in Trenton, only to find old statehouse allies brandishing pitchforks and torches, not the legislative favors he had hoped for.

title: Lessons From the Medias Failures in Its Year With Trump
description: The last year has not been the news medias finest.

title: Monuments Man
description: When historians get around to measuring President Obamas record of protecting Americas public lands from commercial development  its national monuments, parks, forests, wilderness and wildlife refuges  they are likely to rank him high on a list of luminaries that includes both Roosevelts, Jimmy Carter and Bill Clinton. What makes this all the more remarkable is that Mr. Obama came to office as a Chicago urbanite with no obvious passion for environmental stewardship, had no help from Congress and, for his first four years, made little use of his executive authority to protect the federal estate from commercial encroachment. Indeed, his second inaugural address said a great deal about using those lands to produce energy and very little about conservation.

title: Nuclear Power, Debated
description: Given concerns about global warming, should we promote greater use of nuclear energy?

title: Lesbians Invented Hipsters
description: CHICAGO  At a holiday crafts fair, a cute woman with a half-shaved head and a septum piercing pushed a tin toward me. Smell this  it smells awesome, she said, smiling. People brushed past me; the sun lit the womans head like a halo.

title: Taiwans President Accuses China of Renewed Intimidation
description: BEIJING  President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan sharply criticized Chinas leaders on Saturday, saying they had resorted to military and economic threats in order to intimidate the island.

title: How to Become a Superager
description: Think about the people in your life who are 65 or older. Some of them are experiencing the usual mental difficulties of old age, like forgetfulness or a dwindling attention span. Yet others somehow manage to remain mentally sharp. My father-in-law, a retired doctor, is 83 and he still edits books and runs several medical websites.

title: H.R. Haldeman's Notes from Oct. 22, 1968
description: During a phone call on the night of Oct. 22, 1968, Richard M. Nixon told his closest aide (and future chief of staff) H.R. Haldeman to "monkey wrench" President Lyndon B. Johnson's efforts to begin peace negotiations over the Vietnam War.

title: Nixons Vietnam Treachery
description: Richard M. Nixon always denied it: to David Frost, to historians and to Lyndon B. Johnson, who had the strongest suspicions and the most cause for outrage at his successors rumored treachery. To them all, Nixon insisted that he had not sabotaged Johnsons 1968 peace initiative to bring the war in Vietnam to an early conclusion. My God. I would never do anything to encourage South Vietnam not to come to the table, Nixon told Johnson, in a conversation captured on the White House taping system.

title: The World Welcomes 2017
description: From Beijing, China to Mosul, Iraq, people celebrated the final moments of 2016.

title: The World Welcomes 2017
description: From Beijing, China to Mosul, Iraq, people said farewell to 2016 final moments.

title: The World Welcomes 2017
description: From Beijing, China to Mosul, Iraq, people said farewell to 2016 final moments.

title: What Do We Know?
description: The secret to happiness in almost any relationship is knowing what not to say. Ask your new love about her old loves and youll learn more than you want to know, and hear things youll never be able to unhear. Start telling your teacher that your dog ate your homework while your grandma was being rushed to the hospital, and hell have even less patience with you than if you just say, I blew it.

title: U.N. Encourages, but Stops Short of Endorsing, Syria Cease-Fire
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The United Nations Security Council on Saturday unanimously endorsed a resolution encouraging a new cease-fire in the war in Syria, adding international support for an agreement brokered by Russia and Turkey that has been in force for two days.

title: F. Ross Johnson, Symbol of 80s Corporate Excess, Dies at 85
description: F. Ross Johnson, who as chief executive of RJR Nabisco instigated an era-defining takeover struggle that was chronicled in film and a best-selling book and made him a symbol of corporate greed, died on Thursday at his home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 85.

title: Rolling in the Aisles
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Happy new year!

title: Chief Justice Salutes Trial Judges for Tackling Daunting Workload
description: WASHINGTON  Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., noting that the number of cases on the Supreme Courts docket has declined, used his year-end report on the state of the federal judiciary to praise federal trial judges, whose workload is by many measures much larger.

title: Terrorist Attack at Nightclub in Istanbul Kills Dozens
description: BURSA, Turkey  At least 39 people were killed and dozens more were wounded when a single gunman attacked a crowded Istanbul nightclub about an hour after midnight on New Years Day, Turkish officials said.
